description: CompTIA Security+ professionals help to implement, administer and maintain a secure computing environment for any organization. Viewers will hear about different topics and objectives discussed in this course including different areas of security, threats and vulnerabilities, cryptography, and other additional topics and will attain knowledge and skills to identify security issues, to mitigate and deter threats, to apply security controls and implement and maintain an organization’s security policies.

episodes.description: CompTIA Security+ professionals help to implement, administer and maintain a secure computing environment for any organization.  Earning the Security+ certification is foundational for anyone who wants to start a network security career. Learners will have attain knowledge and skills to identify security issues, to mitigate and deter threats, to apply security controls and implement and maintain an organization's security policies.  Many organizations that handle sensitive financial or medical data seek the skills of CompTIA Security+ professional when filling IT position.
episodes.title: Introduction to Security+
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.728
[SOUND] In this video,

2
00:00:01.728 --> 00:00:07.183
we're gonna take a look at
the CompTIA Security+ certification.

3
00:00:07.183 --> 00:00:11.433
If you're not familiar with it, the
Security+ certification is an intermediate

4
00:00:11.433 --> 00:00:15.684
level cert from CompTIA and is designed to
show that you have the relevant knowledge

5
00:00:15.684 --> 00:00:18.760
and skills to function
as a IT security worker.

6
00:00:18.760 --> 00:00:21.660
IT security is extremely
important these days.

7
00:00:21.660 --> 00:00:25.710
It’s a rare that a week goes by that you
don't hear about a company being hacked or

8
00:00:25.710 --> 00:00:28.140
having their credit card database stolen.

9
00:00:28.140 --> 00:00:33.160
And it’s really becoming a big, major
issue and companies are recognizing that.

10
00:00:33.160 --> 00:00:36.260
And so more and
more people are becoming IT workers.

11
00:00:36.260 --> 00:00:37.750
IT security workers.

12
00:00:37.750 --> 00:00:40.320
And if you wanna work in the security
field, where do you get started?

13
00:00:40.320 --> 00:00:44.475
Well, the Security+ certification
is really the best place for that.

14
00:00:44.475 --> 00:00:48.376
Security+ is not gonna teach you
how to break into a web server and

15
00:00:48.376 --> 00:00:51.650
how to protect the credit card
database all by yourself.

16
00:00:51.650 --> 00:00:55.330
What is gonna teach you are the
fundamental skills that you need to

17
00:00:55.330 --> 00:01:00.285
understand before you're able to move to
that level, to the more advanced levels.

18
00:01:00.285 --> 00:01:03.340
Security+ is really designed for
almost everyone.

19
00:01:03.340 --> 00:01:08.690
It is a hard exam, so you don't
necessarily want the male room clerk or

20
00:01:08.690 --> 00:01:13.158
the cafeteria workers to be able to go and
get the Security+ certification.

21
00:01:13.158 --> 00:01:15.900
But if you work in IT,
if you're a systems admin or

22
00:01:15.900 --> 00:01:20.060
a network admin somebody like that and
security falls under your per view,

23
00:01:20.060 --> 00:01:22.540
well this is something that
you really need to know.

24
00:01:22.540 --> 00:01:27.520
But if you're going to be focused as
a penetration tester, as a IT security

25
00:01:27.520 --> 00:01:31.180
auditor, as a security officer,
Security+ is really a requirement.

26
00:01:31.180 --> 00:01:33.860
This is foundational knowledge
that everyone working in IT

27
00:01:33.860 --> 00:01:35.350
security should have.

28
00:01:35.350 --> 00:01:38.220
Let's take a look at CompTIA's
career road map, right?

29
00:01:38.220 --> 00:01:41.710
CompTIA likes to map all
certifications to particular careers.

30
00:01:41.710 --> 00:01:45.480
And the very top career field
is information security,

31
00:01:45.480 --> 00:01:46.940
it's on top for a reason.

32
00:01:46.940 --> 00:01:51.140
It's on top because there is a lack
of IT security workers right now.

33
00:01:51.140 --> 00:01:53.150
Companies are trying to hire
as many as they can, and

34
00:01:53.150 --> 00:01:55.570
there just aren't enough
of them out there.

35
00:01:55.570 --> 00:01:58.351
Well, if you look the beginner and
novice level for

36
00:01:58.351 --> 00:02:02.800
that is the IT fundamentals and
A+ certification that we've seen before.

37
00:02:02.800 --> 00:02:07.150
But as you move to the intermediate level
look at the amount of certifications

38
00:02:07.150 --> 00:02:08.170
that are available.

39
00:02:08.170 --> 00:02:09.680
There's Cisco certification.

40
00:02:09.680 --> 00:02:14.830
There's one's from (ISC)² and
EC council and other vendors like that.

41
00:02:14.830 --> 00:02:18.270
And CompTIA has a number
of certifications also.

42
00:02:18.270 --> 00:02:20.690
And the one that I'm talking
about right now is Security+.

43
00:02:20.690 --> 00:02:27.850
Now, you'll also notice that CompTIA CSA+,
so the Cybersecurity analyst+.

44
00:02:27.850 --> 00:02:29.780
Why two certifications at the same level?

45
00:02:29.780 --> 00:02:31.195
Well they're actually
a little bit different.

46
00:02:31.195 --> 00:02:34.650
Security+ is fundamentals, right?

47
00:02:34.650 --> 00:02:36.780
General concepts, theory,

48
00:02:36.780 --> 00:02:39.625
knowledge that everyone should have
that's working in IT security.

49
00:02:39.625 --> 00:02:43.930
CSA+ is a little more practical,
a little more hands on.

50
00:02:43.930 --> 00:02:46.670
So actually understanding how
attacks are pulled off and

51
00:02:46.670 --> 00:02:49.840
how to protect those servers and
going that extra step.

52
00:02:49.840 --> 00:02:54.450
That's important also if you're
the actual security worker, right?

53
00:02:54.450 --> 00:02:57.722
If you're a network admin, that knowledge
isn't necessarily relevant to you,

54
00:02:57.722 --> 00:02:59.540
Security+ is.

55
00:02:59.540 --> 00:03:03.310
But if you are a penetration tester or
a security officer

56
00:03:03.310 --> 00:03:08.170
you wanna do a Security+ and the CSA+,
both of them go together really well.

57
00:03:08.170 --> 00:03:10.110
But Security+ is the starting point.

58
00:03:10.110 --> 00:03:13.870
It's the intermediate level the one that
we kind of kick off with in security.

59
00:03:13.870 --> 00:03:17.660
And then we move up to the advanced
level and beyond from there, right?

60
00:03:17.660 --> 00:03:21.590
Well let's talk a little bit about
what's on the certification, right?

61
00:03:21.590 --> 00:03:24.120
CompTIA publishes all of the exam
objectors rights on their website.

62
00:03:24.120 --> 00:03:26.480
You can go to CompTIA.org
to pull the full list.

63
00:03:26.480 --> 00:03:29.340
This exact document that
I'm looking at right here.

64
00:03:29.340 --> 00:03:31.880
And what they do is they
take all the topics and

65
00:03:31.880 --> 00:03:33.980
they divide them up into domains.

66
00:03:33.980 --> 00:03:36.380
And so I've got the different
domains pulled up on my screen here.

67
00:03:36.380 --> 00:03:37.830
Six different domains.

68
00:03:37.830 --> 00:03:39.670
Some are more important than others,
right?

69
00:03:39.670 --> 00:03:44.680
Where some of them make up 20% of
the exam, others make up just 12%, right?

70
00:03:44.680 --> 00:03:48.750
So they've geared it based on
the importance level of the knowledge

71
00:03:48.750 --> 00:03:49.720
in the career, right?

72
00:03:49.720 --> 00:03:52.210
And they start with network security.

73
00:03:52.210 --> 00:03:55.580
If your network is not secured it doesn't
matter how much effort you put behind

74
00:03:55.580 --> 00:03:57.410
securing your workstations and servers.

75
00:03:57.410 --> 00:03:58.520
Your network has been compromised.

76
00:03:58.520 --> 00:03:59.990
Your data will be caught in transit.

77
00:03:59.990 --> 00:04:02.910
So, securing a network is
where they kick it off.

78
00:04:02.910 --> 00:04:05.570
How do we protect data in motion?

79
00:04:05.570 --> 00:04:09.260
In domain two, Compliance and
Operational Security.

80
00:04:09.260 --> 00:04:10.790
This is really important.

81
00:04:10.790 --> 00:04:13.390
You might have government
agencies that have restrictions,

82
00:04:13.390 --> 00:04:16.310
that have regulations in place
that you need to follow.

83
00:04:16.310 --> 00:04:20.800
Or you might just internally have your
own requirements for any network gear or

84
00:04:20.800 --> 00:04:23.980
servers or workstations that are on
your network, you have these rules for

85
00:04:23.980 --> 00:04:25.370
how they get secured.

86
00:04:25.370 --> 00:04:28.620
Well, a lot of us do a great job
of securing the devices at first.

87
00:04:28.620 --> 00:04:30.150
But then they get deployed and
they run for

88
00:04:30.150 --> 00:04:32.655
six months and they start getting less.

89
00:04:32.655 --> 00:04:35.885
And less secure as people mess with them,
so how do we make sure that we maintain

90
00:04:35.885 --> 00:04:38.825
compliance, what kind of
processes do we need in place?

91
00:04:38.825 --> 00:04:41.175
That's what covered in domain two.

92
00:04:41.175 --> 00:04:43.805
In domain three we have threats and
vulnerabilities.

93
00:04:43.805 --> 00:04:46.082
If you're going to
protect your environment,

94
00:04:46.082 --> 00:04:48.502
you need to know what
you're protecting it from.

95
00:04:48.502 --> 00:04:50.952
And so we address all the different
threats that are out there.

96
00:04:50.952 --> 00:04:53.932
Some of the vulnerabilities, the
weaknesses that we have on our networks,

97
00:04:53.932 --> 00:04:57.532
and in our systems so that we understand
how we can start to protect from those.

98
00:04:58.756 --> 00:05:02.396
Then we focus on in Applications,
Data and Host Security.

99
00:05:02.396 --> 00:05:05.896
Now that we understand Threats and
Vulnerabilities how do we protect, right?

100
00:05:05.896 --> 00:05:09.146
What can we put in place to protect
our data, to protect our host,

101
00:05:09.146 --> 00:05:12.436
the actual work stations, the laptops,
phones, tablets, whatever?

102
00:05:12.436 --> 00:05:13.106
How do we protect them?

103
00:05:14.290 --> 00:05:17.240
Then we get into access control and
identify management in domain five,

104
00:05:17.240 --> 00:05:20.800
and this is where we talk about
physical access into a building,

105
00:05:20.800 --> 00:05:24.710
how do you get through a door, how do we
identify people are who they say they are.

106
00:05:24.710 --> 00:05:27.130
And not just physical security but
logical also.

107
00:05:27.130 --> 00:05:30.300
If somebody's logging into an email
server, how do you know that it's actually

108
00:05:30.300 --> 00:05:32.630
them and
not just somebody that stole the password?

109
00:05:32.630 --> 00:05:35.000
So how do we handle identity management?

110
00:05:35.000 --> 00:05:37.680
And then in the last domain
we have cryptography.

111
00:05:37.680 --> 00:05:41.920
Encryption is a key component in
securing a network, whether it be

112
00:05:41.920 --> 00:05:46.030
email encryption or website encryption or
generalized encryption like IPSec.

113
00:05:46.030 --> 00:05:48.930
Those are all key things that
we need to be familiar with

114
00:05:48.930 --> 00:05:51.040
to know what options we have.

115
00:05:51.040 --> 00:05:55.520
Right, if I say, I need to send a secure
email, okay, well, what choices do I have?

116
00:05:55.520 --> 00:05:56.760
How can I do that?

117
00:05:56.760 --> 00:05:58.430
I need to understand what
options are available to me,

118
00:05:58.430 --> 00:06:00.460
and that's what the cryptography
section is all about.

119
00:06:00.460 --> 00:06:04.920
All right, because there's good
encryption and there's bad encryption.

120
00:06:04.920 --> 00:06:08.750
Not all encryption is created equal,
so we need to know the difference.

121
00:06:08.750 --> 00:06:11.040
All right, well,
that's what's on the exam.

122
00:06:11.040 --> 00:06:13.200
Those are the general topics
that are gonna be covered.

123
00:06:13.200 --> 00:06:14.610
What about the exam itself?

124
00:06:14.610 --> 00:06:18.460
Well, this is another nice one because
it's one exam, one certification.

125
00:06:18.460 --> 00:06:22.670
So you take a single exam, you pass it,
and you're now Security+ certified.

126
00:06:22.670 --> 00:06:25.730
The exam itself I've got
the details pulled up here.

127
00:06:25.730 --> 00:06:28.010
It's a maximum of 90 questions.

128
00:06:28.010 --> 00:06:30.420
Notice how they don't tell you
exactly how many questions.

129
00:06:30.420 --> 00:06:33.860
That's because the bulk of
the exam is multiple choice, but

130
00:06:33.860 --> 00:06:37.460
then there are practical, what they call
performance-based questions on there

131
00:06:37.460 --> 00:06:40.920
where they might give you the command
prompt for a Windows machine.

132
00:06:40.920 --> 00:06:44.440
Or they might give you the web interface
for a router and you have to go in and

133
00:06:44.440 --> 00:06:48.350
apply security settings to it to
properly implement a secure device,

134
00:06:48.350 --> 00:06:49.640
maybe secure a wireless network.

135
00:06:49.640 --> 00:06:51.100
You've gotta punch in
some wireless settings.

136
00:06:51.100 --> 00:06:54.200
So those are hands on type of activities.

137
00:06:54.200 --> 00:06:58.260
When you have those, it reduces the total
number of questions on the exam.

138
00:06:58.260 --> 00:07:02.030
So 90 is the maximum,
you'll likely have less.

139
00:07:02.030 --> 00:07:05.390
You get 90 minutes to take the exam
which is not a ton of time.

140
00:07:05.390 --> 00:07:08.300
Right, so you need to spend less
than one minute per question

141
00:07:08.300 --> 00:07:10.590
otherwise you're gonna run
out of time on the exam.

142
00:07:10.590 --> 00:07:15.050
And you need to score a 750 or
higher out of a 900 points scale.

143
00:07:15.050 --> 00:07:18.560
So you don't have to be perfect, you can
get some wrong and you'll still pass

144
00:07:18.560 --> 00:07:23.790
the exam, it is a challenging exam so
they do allow some leeway there, right?

145
00:07:23.790 --> 00:07:28.030
Now the exam itself is $311 US you can
pull up foreign pricing if you're in

146
00:07:28.030 --> 00:07:32.450
another country right on CompTIA's
website or on the Vue website.

147
00:07:32.450 --> 00:07:33.536
Now I mention Vue, who is that?

148
00:07:33.536 --> 00:07:36.730
The exam is proctored through
a company called Pearson Vue.

149
00:07:36.730 --> 00:07:38.274
Vue is V-U-E.

150
00:07:38.274 --> 00:07:42.020
And they have testing
centers all over the world.

151
00:07:42.020 --> 00:07:45.220
So when you're ready to take the exam
you just look up the nearest Vue

152
00:07:45.220 --> 00:07:46.240
testing centers to you.

153
00:07:46.240 --> 00:07:48.550
And the way way you can do that
is by going to the website.

154
00:07:48.550 --> 00:07:50.955
The website is vue.com.

155
00:07:50.955 --> 00:07:54.820
Vue.com and when you go there you'll
see a link at the top of the site for

156
00:07:54.820 --> 00:07:56.140
test takers.

157
00:07:56.140 --> 00:07:59.149
And when you jump onto the page you can
tell what kind of exam you are looking to

158
00:07:59.149 --> 00:08:01.720
take cuz they do testing for
a number of different providers.

159
00:08:01.720 --> 00:08:04.850
I'm gonna type in CompTIA, right?

160
00:08:04.850 --> 00:08:08.080
And once I'm there,
I'm on the CompTIA page and from here,

161
00:08:08.080 --> 00:08:13.150
I can go down to find a test center and
locate the nearest test center to me.

162
00:08:13.150 --> 00:08:19.080
So, let's say that I'm in New York,
New York and so,

163
00:08:19.080 --> 00:08:22.300
I'll punch that in and find out how many
testing centers, I'm sure there's a ton.

164
00:08:22.300 --> 00:08:24.920
And so
I can see just right here in Manhattan or

165
00:08:24.920 --> 00:08:27.220
wherever we got at least
five that are nearby.

166
00:08:27.220 --> 00:08:31.390
And so, I can find the nearest testing
center to me, go on to the site,

167
00:08:31.390 --> 00:08:34.360
register for the exam and
jump over and take that test.

168
00:08:34.360 --> 00:08:37.690
When you take the test, it is computer
based, so it is immediately graded and

169
00:08:37.690 --> 00:08:39.870
as soon as you complete it, you will
know whether you passed or failed,

170
00:08:39.870 --> 00:08:41.400
right there on the screen.

171
00:08:41.400 --> 00:08:43.610
You get the certification,
you put it on your resume and

172
00:08:43.610 --> 00:08:46.340
now you're ready to jump in and
start that IT security career.

173
00:08:47.430 --> 00:08:48.540
All right, so what's next?

174
00:08:48.540 --> 00:08:51.650
Well if this is the certification for
you, then it's study time.

175
00:08:51.650 --> 00:08:53.940
You need to hit the books or videos.

176
00:08:53.940 --> 00:08:55.510
Go to sites like ITPro TV.

177
00:08:55.510 --> 00:08:56.820
You can watch our video content.

178
00:08:56.820 --> 00:08:59.860
We've produced videos for
all the exam objectives for

179
00:08:59.860 --> 00:09:02.080
the CompTIA Security+ certification.

180
00:09:02.080 --> 00:09:04.012
You can watch those study up and

181
00:09:04.012 --> 00:09:07.610
go and take that exam or whatever other
vendors you choose to use as many great

182
00:09:07.610 --> 00:09:11.270
books that are out there by companies
like [INAUDIBLE] and Sidebacks.

183
00:09:11.270 --> 00:09:13.480
They cover a lot of the content and
those are great providers too.

184
00:09:13.480 --> 00:09:16.490
CompTIA also has resources on their page.

185
00:09:16.490 --> 00:09:19.800
If you go to CompTIA.org You can find
a lot of great study resources there.

186
00:09:19.800 --> 00:09:22.520
Take the exam and
you get the certification.

187
00:09:22.520 --> 00:09:23.850
Where do you go after that?

188
00:09:23.850 --> 00:09:28.020
Well the next step is really the CSA+,
the cyber security analyst,

189
00:09:28.020 --> 00:09:31.050
that's where you really start getting
a little more hands on with things.

190
00:09:31.050 --> 00:09:34.310
But there's other certifications
out there also like EC counsel,

191
00:09:34.310 --> 00:09:36.050
certified ethical hacker.

192
00:09:36.050 --> 00:09:39.190
There's the certified
forensics investigator.

193
00:09:39.190 --> 00:09:43.890
There's a number of other certification
for other vendors like, not Microsoft, but

194
00:09:43.890 --> 00:09:46.580
Cisco where they have their firewall
certifications, or Juniper,

195
00:09:46.580 --> 00:09:47.890
with their SSG's.

196
00:09:47.890 --> 00:09:50.860
Those are great certifications
to move into also.

197
00:09:50.860 --> 00:09:53.290
All is part of that security career.

198
00:09:53.290 --> 00:09:55.270
Security is a hot button today.

199
00:09:55.270 --> 00:09:57.855
So a lot of companies are looking for
certified professionals.

200
00:09:57.855 --> 00:10:00.010
Security+ is the starting point.

201
00:10:00.010 --> 00:10:03.090
All the other certifications
are about evolving your career and

202
00:10:03.090 --> 00:10:07.150
increasing your knowledge but
Security+ is where we start.

203
00:10:07.150 --> 00:10:08.620
All right.
Well, hopefully that's a good overview for

204
00:10:08.620 --> 00:10:09.450
you on Security+.

205
00:10:09.450 --> 00:10:11.800
We've seen what's on the exam and
who it's tailored for.

206
00:10:11.800 --> 00:10:12.870
If you're studying for it,

207
00:10:12.870 --> 00:10:15.375
best of luck in your studies and
we hope to see you online.

208
00:10:15.375 --> 00:10:18.714

00:06:50,350 --> 00:06:51,980

01:43:55,930 --> 01:43:59,400

wait til one of your users is connecting

2269
01:44:20,014 --> 01:44:21,160
>> Yep, mm-hm.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee introduce Risk Concepts that all IT security professionals should understand.  They define what is risk and the general types of risk.  They also show the cycle of risk analysis that is constant and not just a single process but something that is done continuously.  With that understanding that risk need to be identified and analyzed, the team tells us how to appropriately deal with risk that arise within our organization.
episodes.title: Risk Concepts

WEBVTT

1

Welcome to ITProTV,

2
00:00:06.761 --> 00:00:08.262
[MUSIC]

3

>> You're watching ITProTV.

4

>> Welcome to another great

5

I'm your host Ronnie Wong and today,

6

we'll be taking a look at
what CompTIA Security+.

We're specifically gonna be addressing

8

9

And here to help us out to understand

10

Cherokee, welcome back to our show and

11

12

13

14

Risks are something that

15

really need to be aware of and

16

here we are even in Security+.

17

But also we're gonna be talking about it
a little bit later today in Project+.

18

So it's not just something

19

It's in our businesses every day.

20
00:00:56.630 --> 00:00:58.140
It's something we have to think about.

21

>> So let's go ahead and

22

So Cherokee, just explain to us briefly
in terms of a security professional and

23

24

>> Yeah, so I think that it really
helps to look at the definitions here.

25

If you wanna go ahead and look at my
computer, I hate to do that to you, but

26
00:01:15.240 --> 00:01:19.470
let's look at them and then we'll go
ahead and talk about them individually.

27
00:01:19.470 --> 00:01:23.400
By definition,
a risk is the likelihood and impact or

28
00:01:23.400 --> 00:01:28.940
consequence of a threat actor
exercising a vulnerability.

29
00:01:28.940 --> 00:01:30.610
And I know it's very wordy there.

30

That's why we need you
guys to be able to see it.

31

On the exam, you can identify the proper
vocabulary term and the definition.

32
00:01:37.120 --> 00:01:41.920
But I think we really also need to make
sure we understand all of the terms

33
00:01:41.920 --> 00:01:43.770
that go ahead and define risks.

34
00:01:43.770 --> 00:01:46.004
So that's what we'll go ahead and do here.

35

>> All right Cherokee, so I understand
that there's actually also different types

36
00:01:49.715 --> 00:01:52.110
of risks that we have
to actually encounter.

37
00:01:52.110 --> 00:01:53.790
So let's go over those
different types of risks.

38
00:01:53.790 --> 00:01:54.669
What do we wanna begin with?

39
00:01:56.380 --> 00:02:00.493
>> Well, let's first start and look at
the actual other terms that we have here.

40
00:02:00.493 --> 00:02:01.343
>> Okay.

>> If you look at the definition

00:02:05.740 --> 00:02:07.250
>> Okay.
>> So first of all,

45
00:02:14.660 --> 00:02:15.565
>> Mm-hm.

46
00:02:15.565 --> 00:02:18.915
>> And the terms are similar but
they mean completely different things.

47
00:02:18.915 --> 00:02:21.910
So Ronnie, have you ever heard
threat actor and vector before?

48
00:02:21.910 --> 00:02:25.650
>> Well, let's just say for the sake of
our argument, I have not heard of it.

49
00:02:25.650 --> 00:02:27.260
>> Great!
>> And so please Cherokee,

50
00:02:27.260 --> 00:02:30.458
what is the difference between
threat actor and threat vector?

51
00:02:30.458 --> 00:02:35.470
>> Yeah, so
a threat vector is going to be how and

52
00:02:35.470 --> 00:02:39.960
your threat actor is going to be who?

53
00:02:39.960 --> 00:02:42.390
As I guess will be easiest
way that I can explain it.

54
00:02:42.390 --> 00:02:47.590
So for instance, lets say you go ahead and
receive some kinda of virus,

55
00:02:47.590 --> 00:02:51.980
malware attached from a download,
from attachment, from an email.

56
00:02:51.980 --> 00:02:59.720
So your actual vector, okay,
would be the email, that attachment.

57
00:02:59.720 --> 00:03:02.980
And then your actor,
your threat actor, your bad actor,

58
00:03:02.980 --> 00:03:06.150
would be whomever sent or
distributed that email.

59
00:03:06.150 --> 00:03:08.180
So hopefully that makes sense for
you guys,

60
00:03:08.180 --> 00:03:12.612
because before we continue I just want to

61
00:03:12.612 --> 00:03:16.120
>> Okay, all right, so Cherokee, now
once we actually understand that idea of

>> Sure, so a vulnerability by definition,

68
00:03:40.160 --> 00:03:45.220
So Ronnie, something that I'm sure you're

00:03:45.220 --> 00:03:51.370
and not just Security+ but sans, NIST,
we look at a lot of categorization.

70
00:03:51.370 --> 00:03:54.680
So we have categories for everything,

71
00:03:54.680 --> 00:03:56.840
we're going to be looking at

72
00:03:56.840 --> 00:04:00.240
And then I'll also show you some that
we don't have to worry about for

73
00:04:00.240 --> 00:04:01.610
this certification.

74
00:04:01.610 --> 00:04:05.050
But we might wanna just kind

75

So yeah, a vulnerability can exist, okay?

76
00:04:08.280 --> 00:04:10.500
It doesn't have to be acted upon,

77
00:04:10.500 --> 00:04:15.600

systems, that could be a vulnerability.

78
00:04:15.600 --> 00:04:17.380
Poor training for your company.

79
00:04:17.380 --> 00:04:22.270
Not letting them know about certain
types of issues that are out there,

80
00:04:22.270 --> 00:04:24.180
so that would be a vulnerability.

81
00:04:25.430 --> 00:04:28.685
And then we look at this term of threat,
okay?

82
00:04:28.685 --> 00:04:33.345
So if we see threat, it's the potential
for threat agent or threat actor.

83
00:04:33.345 --> 00:04:34.655
Same terminology there.

84
00:04:34.655 --> 00:04:37.525
You may see it worded
a little bit differently.

85
00:04:37.525 --> 00:04:42.575
But basically that's something or
someone that may trigger that

86
00:04:42.575 --> 00:04:47.285
vulnerability that we just saw,
accidentally or exploited intentionally.

87
00:04:47.285 --> 00:04:51.380
So a lot of times, our vulnerabilities

88
00:04:51.380 --> 00:04:56.080
can even be triggered accidentally,
a lot of that happens in businesses.

89
00:04:56.080 --> 00:05:03.720
So again, categorizing it as intentional
or unintentional, they could go ahead and

90
00:05:03.720 --> 00:05:07.580
exercise a vulnerability that is
to go ahead and breach security.

91
00:05:07.580 --> 00:05:10.650
So we'll talk about security

00:05:10.650 --> 00:05:14.320
anything that basically defies your

00:05:14.320 --> 00:05:17.292
fall on to that realm of security breach.

94
00:05:18.530 --> 00:05:22.820
Also, the path or

95
00:05:22.820 --> 00:05:26.100
It can be refered to as the threat

97
00:05:29.610 --> 00:05:31.840
>> So let's make sure we can

00:05:31.840 --> 00:05:33.980
You gave us an example of a vulnerability,

00:05:37.485 --> 00:05:41.580
>> An example of a threat

00:05:41.580 --> 00:05:43.370
it could be a disgruntled employee.

102
00:05:43.370 --> 00:05:44.700
It could be a hacker

103
00:05:46.510 --> 00:05:50.400

104
00:05:51.400 --> 00:05:57.130
It could be,
what was an unlocked door, maybe.

105
00:05:57.130 --> 00:05:59.081
>> Yeah.
>> Even just something simple like that,

106
00:05:59.081 --> 00:06:00.335

107

00:06:04.304 --> 00:06:08.290

00:06:08.290 --> 00:06:10.560
How we gonna prioritize them,

00:06:13.360 --> 00:06:16.670
We shouldn't focus as much
attention on them and

00:06:16.670 --> 00:06:21.030
that brings us to our last terminology

113
00:06:21.030 --> 00:06:26.020

would have an unlimited budget for

114
00:06:26.020 --> 00:06:28.540
my organization, but

115
00:06:28.540 --> 00:06:29.930
Since and so sometimes we have to pick and

116
00:06:29.930 --> 00:06:34.180
choose as to where we gonna be allocating
our budget for that particular quarter.

117
00:06:34.180 --> 00:06:40.160
So, a control is a system or
procedure put in place to mitigate risk.

118
00:06:40.160 --> 00:06:43.440
So we're trying to either prevent it or

119
00:06:43.440 --> 00:06:47.640
reduce the impact of it, or potentially

120
00:06:47.640 --> 00:06:50.680
So we'll also take a look at

121
00:06:50.680 --> 00:06:53.360
>> All right, so Cherokee, now that

133
00:07:31.750 --> 00:07:36.330
Now depending on certain organizations and

134

136

275

where they don't ever leave their

00:15:22.220 --> 00:15:26.270

00:15:26.270 --> 00:15:26.950
>> Good and bad.

278
00:15:26.950 --> 00:15:28.880
>> But at the same time, it can be bad,

because then a lot of times more
things can go on and personality

issues that can end up happening when

00:15:38.590 --> 00:15:43.612

00:15:59.477 --> 00:16:01.114
>> We don't want anyone hurt, but just.

>> Um-hm.

>> Yup.
>> So I want to make sure that.

00:16:03.598 --> 00:16:04.896
We're able to go ahead and

00:16:04.896 --> 00:16:07.909

292
00:16:07.909 --> 00:16:09.558
>> Yeah, and then the same thing, right,

293
00:16:09.558 --> 00:16:12.990
they know that they're not leaving
anybody in the lurch at the same time.

294
00:16:12.990 --> 00:16:15.860
A lot of people feel a little bit
more insecure about their job when

00:16:15.860 --> 00:16:18.300

00:16:18.300 --> 00:16:19.987
But it is something that

00:16:19.987 --> 00:16:22.670

00:16:22.670 --> 00:16:26.940
The other thing about mandatory vacations
that really is good in terms of security

00:16:26.940 --> 00:16:29.710
Is that it gives us
a chance to actually review

00:16:29.710 --> 00:16:33.470

301
00:16:33.470 --> 00:16:36.780
So if there is any, hopefully it's
not because of security incident,

302
00:16:36.780 --> 00:16:40.190
but even with security policies,
they can actually review and

00:16:40.190 --> 00:16:41.910

304
00:16:41.910 --> 00:16:43.705
So mandatory vacations are good.
>> Auditing.

305
00:16:43.705 --> 00:16:45.780
>> Yeah, auditing.
>> Perfect times for audits, yeah.

00:16:45.780 --> 00:16:47.400
>> Those are kind of some of the things.

But yeah, mandatory vacations, they can

Sometimes you do have to take a vacation

different tasks.

So that's job rotation, and

00:18:09.540 --> 00:18:13.550
We'll see this a lot throughout
Security+ because you always wanna be

00:18:13.550 --> 00:18:17.242
very translucent, okay, with security.

00:18:17.242 --> 00:18:18.970
You wanna make sure you're letting people,

We don't keep our password lists, we're

00:18:36.600 --> 00:18:40.418

00:18:40.418 --> 00:18:44.230

345
00:18:44.230 --> 00:18:46.600
Job rotation, separation of duty and

00:18:46.600 --> 00:18:49.280
mandatory vacations are all
pretty important here.

347
00:18:49.280 --> 00:18:51.960
>> They really are,
the job rotation's a very good thing for

00:18:51.960 --> 00:18:55.920
a company as well, because it allows them

00:18:55.920 --> 00:18:56.880

00:18:56.880 --> 00:19:00.020
The very fact of actually doing

00:19:02.800 --> 00:19:04.970
It allows them to also

weaknesses of that individual, and

00:19:07.020 --> 00:19:11.180
allows us to then be able to understand
their performance and where they are.

355
00:19:11.180 --> 00:19:14.750
So job rotation's also very
important because it does actually

00:19:14.750 --> 00:19:18.110
require everybody to understand
a little bit about that piece,

00:19:18.110 --> 00:19:21.310
especially in the overall

00:19:21.310 --> 00:19:24.950
It's not enough just that you know

You gotta understand where it fits

360
00:19:28.010 --> 00:19:32.410
of that security policy is actually a good

361
00:19:32.410 --> 00:19:35.770

00:19:35.770 --> 00:19:40.226
Accountability is very difficult if only

363
00:19:40.226 --> 00:19:42.215
And once you actually
have something like that,

00:19:42.215 --> 00:19:44.530
it means you don't
really have the control.

365
00:19:44.530 --> 00:19:47.230
By implementing these
separation of duties,

366
00:19:47.230 --> 00:19:51.410
it gives us an automatic way in which we
implement the idea of accountability and

367
00:19:51.410 --> 00:19:55.480
controls by having two people do the job,
like what Cherokee was saying.

368
00:19:55.480 --> 00:19:57.500
So all these are very important measures.

369
00:19:57.500 --> 00:20:02.440
And in terms of policy, right, Cherokee
showed us, at least at the top of her

370
00:20:02.440 --> 00:20:05.400
screen, where it talked about
the importance of these policies for

00:20:05.400 --> 00:20:09.400
security benefits and
helping to reduce the amount of risk.

00:20:09.400 --> 00:20:13.286
A solid security policy and
everything that we've mentioned here,

00:20:13.286 --> 00:20:17.116
it really does actually give

374
00:20:17.116 --> 00:20:17.822
In other words,

00:20:17.822 --> 00:20:21.580
something that everybody can point to

00:20:21.580 --> 00:20:23.290
The policy should answer
the majority of those questions too.

377
00:20:23.290 --> 00:20:27.355
>> Exactly, you're removing any kind
of guesswork out of that situation.

378
00:20:27.355 --> 00:20:30.685
So having these policies in place,
let's say that

379
00:20:30.685 --> 00:20:34.725
it's my company's policy that all guests
must be escorted within a building.

380
00:20:34.725 --> 00:20:36.840
And all the employees must wear ID badges.

381
00:20:36.840 --> 00:20:38.890
So by implementing all these musts, or

382
00:20:38.890 --> 00:20:43.450
these policies, when I see someone
that looks a little out of place,

383
00:20:43.450 --> 00:20:46.670
I don't need to go up to them and
ask them any kind of questions.

384
00:20:46.670 --> 00:20:49.970
I know whom I should contact
because I can identify that person.

385
00:20:49.970 --> 00:20:52.240
Look, they're a guest because
they don't have their badge.

386
00:20:52.240 --> 00:20:55.360
They're not escorted,
something's out of line here.

387
00:20:55.360 --> 00:20:58.740
So having these types of policies
take all of that guesswork right out.

388
00:20:58.740 --> 00:21:02.150
Everything is defined,
what should be done in certain situations.

389
00:21:02.150 --> 00:21:03.890
And lastly if we look at my screen,

390
00:21:03.890 --> 00:21:06.450
there was one more concept
I wanted to address here.

391
00:21:06.450 --> 00:21:10.480
This is going to be our principle or
concept of least privilege.

392
00:21:10.480 --> 00:21:15.460
And what this states is, that we're
only providing enough access for

393
00:21:15.460 --> 00:21:18.140
an individual to perform
their daily duties.

394
00:21:18.140 --> 00:21:19.250
Easy enough, right?

395
00:21:19.250 --> 00:21:22.023
So whether it be technical controls,

396
00:21:22.023 --> 00:21:26.660
okay, like network access controls,
or whether it be physical building.

397
00:21:26.660 --> 00:21:28.160
Talk about wearing those ID badges.

398
00:21:28.160 --> 00:21:33.960
That's great because those ID badges
can also work as key cards for

399
00:21:33.960 --> 00:21:39.210
certain access into the building, so those
are perfect examples of least privilege.

400
00:21:39.210 --> 00:21:43.780
We always want to go ahead and
kind of just shrink our

401
00:21:43.780 --> 00:21:47.310
target area by implementing
the principle of least privilege there.

402
00:21:47.310 --> 00:21:50.320
>> There is no doubt that this is one of
the more frustrating things that people

403
00:21:50.320 --> 00:21:51.220
don't understand.

404
00:21:51.220 --> 00:21:55.290
The principle of least privilege really
has to do with the very fact that not

405
00:21:55.290 --> 00:22:00.080
everyone needs access to everything, but
everybody also needs enough permissions or

406
00:22:00.080 --> 00:22:03.330
enough privileges so
they can do their job.

407
00:22:03.330 --> 00:22:05.130
So when you implement
the principal of least privilege,

408
00:22:05.130 --> 00:22:09.450
you need to make sure of those two things;
that they have enough to do their job, but

409
00:22:09.450 --> 00:22:14.320
at the same time, in terms of privileges,
but at the same not too much beyond that.

410
00:22:14.320 --> 00:22:16.920
So this is where in the IT world,

411
00:22:16.920 --> 00:22:21.650
right, when we start dealing
with things like permissions and

412
00:22:21.650 --> 00:22:27.330
policies over files, we actually do set
up the idea of access control lists.

413
00:22:27.330 --> 00:22:29.210
We do implement that on routers.

414
00:22:29.210 --> 00:22:32.050
We do implement that in
terms of firewall rules.

415
00:22:32.050 --> 00:22:34.145
So that we only allow for
the privileges that we need,

416
00:22:34.145 --> 00:22:38.950
cuz that's very important if we allow
everything, it's very difficult for

417
00:22:38.950 --> 00:22:44.270
us to go ahead and actually be able
to monitor or to track anything.

418
00:22:44.270 --> 00:22:45.590
If we don't allow anything,

419
00:22:45.590 --> 00:22:49.870
it means that you have to have more
administrative control by yourself and

420
00:22:49.870 --> 00:22:53.430
make decisions on everything, which means
you can't do anything else as well.

421
00:22:53.430 --> 00:22:57.612
So implementing that perfect balance
of giving the permissions needed, but

422
00:22:57.612 --> 00:23:00.955
not too much, is actually a very
good balance type of security

423
00:23:00.955 --> 00:23:04.579
policy that really does help
the organization out as well, okay?

424
00:23:04.579 --> 00:23:05.519
All right, Cherokee,

this is going to be a risk

00:23:18.180 --> 00:23:19.870
Using the cloud is so trendy.

00:23:19.870 --> 00:23:21.700
It's so perfect for so many companies.

00:23:21.700 --> 00:23:24.260
It's becoming affordable.

00:23:24.260 --> 00:23:28.540
So there are some special risks that

00:23:28.540 --> 00:23:29.940
I mean you have to think about it,

00:23:38.440 --> 00:23:43.170

00:23:43.170 --> 00:23:48.170
Especially if you're storing any kind of

00:23:48.170 --> 00:23:51.640
control within your environment and

438
00:23:51.640 --> 00:23:54.660

439
00:23:54.660 --> 00:23:56.470
You're not hiring their employees.

00:23:56.470 --> 00:23:59.360

00:24:08.090 --> 00:24:13.430

attacks that are really targeted for

00:24:13.430 --> 00:24:14.890

00:24:14.890 --> 00:24:20.098
So you introduce a whole
another realm of risks.

446
00:24:20.098 --> 00:24:23.890
If that's what the way your company is
going to be going, you need to really look

447
00:24:23.890 --> 00:24:27.320
at that individually and
assess all those particular risks.

448
00:24:27.320 --> 00:24:30.980
>> Yeah, every company is going to treat

449
00:24:30.980 --> 00:24:32.390
depending on their organization.

Some might just use it for

00:24:35.420 --> 00:24:39.260
all their information to a cloud storage

452
00:24:39.260 --> 00:24:41.990

453
00:24:41.990 --> 00:24:45.743
Some need it because it's the heart
of their business to allow for

00:24:45.743 --> 00:24:48.650

00:24:48.650 --> 00:24:53.300
So for example, right here at ITProTV,

00:24:53.300 --> 00:24:57.660

457
00:24:57.660 --> 00:25:01.280
all the members on our site,
would actually be able to get access to.

458
00:25:01.280 --> 00:25:04.928
But once we started taking a look at that,
the other things that you also have

459
00:25:04.928 --> 00:25:07.960
to consider in terms of risk is
the power and the availability.

460
00:25:07.960 --> 00:25:12.340
If one of our servers dies,
the replacement cost of all that stuff.

00:25:12.340 --> 00:25:16.320
So instead what we did was we decided

462
00:25:16.320 --> 00:25:21.720
We off-loaded that risk, essentially

00:25:21.720 --> 00:25:25.690

465
00:25:29.560 --> 00:25:30.810
Same thing with access.

466
00:25:30.810 --> 00:25:34.120
If our Internet connection here

467
00:25:34.120 --> 00:25:35.810
all of our stuff was here that means,well,

468
00:25:35.810 --> 00:25:39.410

469
00:25:39.410 --> 00:25:43.590
So instead you do, you tend to actually
have to worry about those types of things.

470
00:25:43.590 --> 00:25:46.260
In terms of risks, though,
your company balances that out and

471
00:25:46.260 --> 00:25:50.360

talking about in these previous episodes

472
00:25:50.360 --> 00:25:51.680
to help us to understand that.

473
00:25:51.680 --> 00:25:54.947
And so every company is gonna assess
it a little bit differently, but

474
00:25:54.947 --> 00:25:58.213
you have to assess it not only from
the standpoint of availability and

475
00:25:58.213 --> 00:26:00.775
need, but
also with security in mind as well, okay.

476
00:26:00.775 --> 00:26:03.630
All right, Cherokee, anything else
that we need to address here?

477
00:26:03.630 --> 00:26:05.680
>> I think that's about it, Ronnie.

478
00:26:05.680 --> 00:26:09.220
>> All right, well that's a great

00:26:09.220 --> 00:26:12.385
Signing off for ITProTV,

00:26:12.385 --> 00:26:13.772

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee introduce some of the different risk management Strategies.  They explain some of the different types of security policies used and their importance to the overall security strategy.  They emphasize DLP, data loss protection as a key policy in today’s security posture with the advent of BYOD.  More and more devices are onboard and off boarded that need to be sanitized of data existing before use and after use.  Other strategies that are policy driven are also discussed.
episodes.title: Risk Management Strategies

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee introduce some of the way to enforce the policies that are put in place for organizations.  They review the concepts of automated policies for DLP through device loss or theft.  They describe the use of audit policies and user permission issues and even mention some of the technology controls.   Also,  they discuss the importance of change management process as part of risk management.  Lastly, they describe the steps of Incident Management that security professionals must adhere to when security incident occurs.
episodes.title: Risk Management Strategies Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee take a look at the basic forensic procedures that an IT security professional should understand.  They discuss each procedure and describe the purpose and it’s importance in the forensic process.  The describe the basic evidence gathering that must occur when a computer security incident happens for a company.  Even though many may not be a forensic expert, according to the team, every Security+ professional should be familiar with the process to insure that computer evidence is not collected haphazardly so a legal case is not made.
episodes.title: Basic Forensic Procedures

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee discuss some of the different techniques to mitigate and deter security incidences.  They show how to use the event viewer to access different logs in a Windows machine and discuss the ways they help identify when and possibly what security incident occurred.  Also, they discuss additional methods much as implementing IPS and/or IDS into our networks while using the Windows Firewall with Advanced Security to demonstrate andIPS.  Using a wireless access point, Cherokee shows how to setup MAC filtering and describes using 802.1x for authentication as a security mitigation technique.  Lastly, they briefly mention device hardening techniques to help.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee discuss some of the different social engineering attacks that CompTIA Security+ professionals need to be able to identify and mitigate. 00:32:35.604 --> 00:32:41.653
[MUSIC]

598
00:32:41.653 --> 00:32:42.600
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Don delve into the world of vulnerability and penetration testing. They introduce various tools used to determine the ports and systems in use as well as baiting attackers away from critical infrastructure through the use of honeypots and honeynets. They conclude with a brief discussion on the penetration testing process and the different levels in can be performed at.
episodes.title: Vulnerability Scanning
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:15,211 --> 00:00:22,770
[SOUND]

3
00:00:22,770 --> 00:00:33,009
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:33,009 --> 00:00:33,763
All right.

5
00:00:33,763 --> 00:00:36,257
Good morning, good afternoon,
and good evening, and

6
00:00:36,257 --> 00:00:40,480
welcome back to another episode of
"ITProTV", I'm your host Don Pezet.

7
00:00:40,480 --> 00:00:41,630
Back to you on Mr. Nate Copeland.

8
00:00:41,630 --> 00:00:42,330
How's it going Nate?

9
00:00:42,330 --> 00:00:44,050
>> Yeah, pretty good,
Don, pretty good today.

10
00:00:44,050 --> 00:00:48,980
Fired up for yet
another fun show of Security+ with you.

11
00:00:48,980 --> 00:00:51,420
>> Well,
you know it's gonna be over the top

12
00:00:51,420 --> 00:00:53,098
when we've got our matching vests on-
>> [LAUGH]

13
00:00:53,098 --> 00:00:55,581
>> So we are vest buddies

14
00:00:55,581 --> 00:00:57,868
>> [LAUGH]

15
00:00:57,868 --> 00:00:58,469
>> All right.

16
00:00:58,469 --> 00:01:03,613
Well, we've got another episode
of "Security+" up in front of us,

17
00:01:03,613 --> 00:01:08,586
and we're going to be taking a look
at some very technical stuff, but

18
00:01:08,586 --> 00:01:12,741
the way that CompTIA addresses
it is very nontechnical.

19
00:01:12,741 --> 00:01:14,480
So they kind of go a little high level.

20
00:01:14,480 --> 00:01:16,265
I like to go a little
more hands on with it.

21
00:01:16,265 --> 00:01:20,920
But we're going to look at vulnerability,
and penetration testing for

22
00:01:20,920 --> 00:01:22,340
systems, all right?

23
00:01:22,340 --> 00:01:24,960
So, what do we mean when we say that?

24
00:01:24,960 --> 00:01:27,250
Lets just start off real high level.

25
00:01:27,250 --> 00:01:33,290
So, when we talk about
vulnerability scanning,

26
00:01:33,290 --> 00:01:37,090
whatever you want to call it, and
penetration testing, what are those?

27
00:01:37,090 --> 00:01:40,000
So, let's just start there, and
we'll go into kind of how you go about it,

28
00:01:40,000 --> 00:01:42,700
and what the process really involves.

29
00:01:42,700 --> 00:01:46,580
So, when we talk about vulnerabilities,
and

30
00:01:46,580 --> 00:01:48,080
when we talk about penetration testing,

31
00:01:48,080 --> 00:01:53,450
what we're really talking about is how are
the attackers gonna come at you, right?

32
00:01:53,450 --> 00:01:55,660
Every network has an attack surface.

33
00:01:55,660 --> 00:01:59,040
If you're connected to the Internet,
there has to be at least one way for

34
00:01:59,040 --> 00:02:03,070
people to be able to get to you, even if
it is through somebody on the inside.

35
00:02:03,070 --> 00:02:06,160
So attackers are gonna be
looking at whatever they can do,

36
00:02:06,160 --> 00:02:09,610
whatever ways they can find to get
their fingers into your network, and

37
00:02:09,610 --> 00:02:11,850
from there to expand their access.

38
00:02:11,850 --> 00:02:14,540
So, it's up to us to stop that, right?

39
00:02:15,570 --> 00:02:18,590
Vulnerability scanning is one
of the best ways to do that.

40
00:02:18,590 --> 00:02:21,070
That's when we take a look
at our servers and we say,

41
00:02:21,070 --> 00:02:24,640
okay, what possible
vulnerabilities do I have?

42
00:02:24,640 --> 00:02:26,700
What are the ways
an attacker could get in?

43
00:02:27,880 --> 00:02:30,420
And you take a look at
what services you run,

44
00:02:30,420 --> 00:02:34,700
what machines are exposed to the Internet,
what machines aren't, what ports are open,

45
00:02:34,700 --> 00:02:37,680
all the different configuration
things across your systems.

46
00:02:37,680 --> 00:02:40,910
And you look at what you're doing, at
what you're leaving open to an attacker.

47
00:02:42,030 --> 00:02:44,700
Now, finding that information for
us, like when we scan for

48
00:02:44,700 --> 00:02:47,020
vulnerabilities, we're inside the network.

49
00:02:47,020 --> 00:02:50,200
And so we see a lot of things
that the attackers might not.

50
00:02:50,200 --> 00:02:54,900
And so, it's not necessarily
an apples to apples comparison,

51
00:02:54,900 --> 00:02:58,360
because the attacker might
see a much more limited view.

52
00:02:58,360 --> 00:03:01,920
So, that's where the next part comes in,
which is penetration testing.

53
00:03:01,920 --> 00:03:05,340
Penetration testing is where you put
yourself outside the network just like

54
00:03:05,340 --> 00:03:08,460
an attacker and see if you can get in.

55
00:03:08,460 --> 00:03:12,250
See if you can penetrate into that
network to gain access through some of

56
00:03:12,250 --> 00:03:14,515
the vulnerabilities that are available,
all right?

57
00:03:14,515 --> 00:03:18,145
CompTIA very specific in
their terminology on this.

58
00:03:18,145 --> 00:03:19,735
And you'll see it on the exam.

59
00:03:19,735 --> 00:03:22,325
If we look at our objective.

60
00:03:22,325 --> 00:03:25,114
Nate, you have the objectives
pulled up right, 3.7?

61
00:03:25,114 --> 00:03:26,645
>> Mm-hm, yep.
About halfway down on 3.7,

62
00:03:26,645 --> 00:03:29,605
you'll see where it talks
about assessment types,

63
00:03:29,605 --> 00:03:33,755
how you have risks, threats and
vulnerabilities, okay?

64
00:03:33,755 --> 00:03:37,105
A risk, well we always have risk, right?

65
00:03:37,105 --> 00:03:39,846
There is a risk that someone is going
to break into your network, right?

66
00:03:39,846 --> 00:03:42,960
And if they break into your network,
what can they get ahold of?

67
00:03:42,960 --> 00:03:45,060
Well, if you're a financial organization,

68
00:03:45,060 --> 00:03:47,750
they can get ahold of financial records,
right, accounting records.

69
00:03:47,750 --> 00:03:50,550
If you're a bank, for example,
they might be able to get account info and

70
00:03:50,550 --> 00:03:52,540
maybe even get at the money, right?

71
00:03:52,540 --> 00:03:55,930
If you're a hospital, they can get
at your medical records, right?

72
00:03:55,930 --> 00:04:00,570
Whatever data it is that you have that's
sensitive, that's your risk, okay?

73
00:04:00,570 --> 00:04:03,770
And there's always the risk that
somebody could gain access to that.

74
00:04:03,770 --> 00:04:06,360
And then, turn it into whatever
it is that they plan to do.

75
00:04:07,620 --> 00:04:12,280
But, just because there's a risk,
doesn't mean it's going to happen, right?

76
00:04:12,280 --> 00:04:15,293
If you're a hospital, there's a risk
somebody could get your medical records.

77
00:04:15,293 --> 00:04:18,150
But, there isn't necessarily a way for
them to do that.

78
00:04:18,150 --> 00:04:23,050
So, it may be that risk never comes to
fruition, never actually happens, right?

79
00:04:23,050 --> 00:04:25,230
But it is something that we plan for, so

80
00:04:25,230 --> 00:04:28,840
when we talk about risks we're always
talking about preemptive things,

81
00:04:28,840 --> 00:04:32,951
things we can do to mitigate or
minimize that risk coming true, all right?

82
00:04:34,280 --> 00:04:37,070
Then we have vulnerabilities.

83
00:04:37,070 --> 00:04:39,980
If someone wants to get into my system,

84
00:04:39,980 --> 00:04:42,840
my system is going to have
to have a weak point.

85
00:04:42,840 --> 00:04:46,230
A weak point that they're able to take
advantage of to get in, all right?

86
00:04:46,230 --> 00:04:47,640
That's a vulnerability.

87
00:04:47,640 --> 00:04:52,280
So, any weak point in my system,
maybe I have a web server that's

88
00:04:52,280 --> 00:04:55,450
exposed to the Internet that I
haven't updated in six months.

89
00:04:55,450 --> 00:04:58,480
Maybe I have a firewall that
wasn't configured properly, and

90
00:04:58,480 --> 00:05:02,160
it's sitting there, again, in-between
the Internet and my internal network.

91
00:05:02,160 --> 00:05:06,610
Maybe I have an internal employee who has
more permissions than they should, right?

92
00:05:06,610 --> 00:05:09,220
And thus could gain access
to systems if they tried.

93
00:05:09,220 --> 00:05:10,100
That's a vulnerability, all right?

94
00:05:11,100 --> 00:05:13,030
These are all vulnerabilities.

95
00:05:13,030 --> 00:05:15,290
But just because a vulnerability is there,

96
00:05:15,290 --> 00:05:17,670
doesn't mean it's actually
been taken advantage of.

97
00:05:17,670 --> 00:05:20,500
And in some cases it, there may not
be a way to take advantage of it.

98
00:05:20,500 --> 00:05:21,900
There might be a weakness that we know,

99
00:05:21,900 --> 00:05:25,030
but there's not a good way
to take advantage of it.

100
00:05:25,030 --> 00:05:31,480
An example of that would be
like SSL certificates, right?

101
00:05:31,480 --> 00:05:35,450
SSL certs, most of them these
days are 2,048 bit, used for

102
00:05:35,450 --> 00:05:38,250
their key modulus,
which makes them really strong.

103
00:05:38,250 --> 00:05:41,180
And it would take over a billion years for

104
00:05:41,180 --> 00:05:43,340
a single computer to
be able to break that.

105
00:05:43,340 --> 00:05:44,680
That's a vulnerability.

106
00:05:44,680 --> 00:05:45,590
There is a vulnerability.

107
00:05:45,590 --> 00:05:49,040
It is possible that somebody could
sit down with a computer and

108
00:05:49,040 --> 00:05:53,500
spend a billion years and then break
that certificate and get into it, okay?

109
00:05:53,500 --> 00:05:55,010
That's a vulnerability.

110
00:05:55,010 --> 00:05:58,590
But it's not our next word,
which is a threat.

111
00:05:58,590 --> 00:06:03,810
A threat is a vulnerability that can
be taken advantage of, all right?

112
00:06:03,810 --> 00:06:06,780
The weakness of that SSL key,
the weakness, right,

113
00:06:06,780 --> 00:06:07,920
because it would take a billion years.

114
00:06:07,920 --> 00:06:09,760
It doesn’t matter, right?

115
00:06:09,760 --> 00:06:13,490
It’s not a threat because it
just would take too long.

116
00:06:13,490 --> 00:06:15,990
Nobody’s gonna be able to sit there and

117
00:06:15,990 --> 00:06:20,520
spend that amount of time to try and
break my encryption key, all right?

118
00:06:20,520 --> 00:06:23,250
They're gonna move on to other
vulnerabilities that they can take

119
00:06:23,250 --> 00:06:24,240
advantage of.

120
00:06:24,240 --> 00:06:28,080
So, a vulnerability is only
dangerous when it becomes a threat

121
00:06:28,080 --> 00:06:30,270
when there is a way to
take advantage of it.

122
00:06:30,270 --> 00:06:32,190
And just like at Heartbleed, right?

123
00:06:32,190 --> 00:06:33,340
Where they said, okay.

124
00:06:33,340 --> 00:06:37,450
Well, we can't sit there and just break
the private key over time by brute force.

125
00:06:37,450 --> 00:06:38,600
It would take too long.

126
00:06:38,600 --> 00:06:41,950
But if we can get access to the private
key itself through a weakness in

127
00:06:41,950 --> 00:06:44,745
the protocol,
that's a different story, right?

128
00:06:44,745 --> 00:06:47,770
Heartbleed completely broke the SSL for
a little while, and

129
00:06:47,770 --> 00:06:52,620
it did it without brute forcing the keys,
so it was very quick, very fast.

130
00:06:52,620 --> 00:06:57,370
So, brute forcing the key is
a vulnerability, but not a threat.

131
00:06:57,370 --> 00:07:01,590
Compromising the private key through
leaked data in the protocol,

132
00:07:01,590 --> 00:07:06,100
that was a threat, right, and one that was
taken advantage of in quite a few places.

133
00:07:06,100 --> 00:07:08,310
So, that's the difference
in that terminology,

134
00:07:08,310 --> 00:07:10,520
so be familiar with that, right?

135
00:07:10,520 --> 00:07:14,080
So, the difference between a risk,

136
00:07:14,080 --> 00:07:17,520
which is just anywhere we could
potentially lose information.

137
00:07:17,520 --> 00:07:21,270
A vulnerability,
any weak point in our network

138
00:07:21,270 --> 00:07:24,130
regardless of whether it can
be used against us or not.

139
00:07:24,130 --> 00:07:28,380
And then a threat is that weak point
that has a way to be exploited,

140
00:07:28,380 --> 00:07:32,050
to actually be used by an attacker,
all right?

141
00:07:32,050 --> 00:07:36,000
So, the trick to all of this
is your network, my network,

142
00:07:36,000 --> 00:07:39,170
everybody's network has risks and
vulnerabilities.

143
00:07:39,170 --> 00:07:40,890
It just goes without saying.

144
00:07:40,890 --> 00:07:42,290
Everybody has that.

145
00:07:42,290 --> 00:07:46,960
So the trick is you need to find
those before your attacker does.

146
00:07:46,960 --> 00:07:50,548
And, the best way to do that is
through penetration testing and

147
00:07:50,548 --> 00:07:52,116
vulnerability scanning.

148
00:07:52,116 --> 00:07:55,614
You need to be looking at your network and
saying, all right, if I were an attacker,

149
00:07:55,614 --> 00:07:56,418
how could I get in?

150
00:07:56,418 --> 00:08:01,058
How could I get into this system and
do as much damage as possible, right?

151
00:08:01,058 --> 00:08:03,026
Or Maybe it's not about damage.

152
00:08:03,026 --> 00:08:07,138
How can I get into the system and get data
without leaving a foot print behind and

153
00:08:07,138 --> 00:08:10,370
then just get out without
actually damaging anything?

154
00:08:10,370 --> 00:08:13,720
Those are the types of things
that the attacker is thinking of.

155
00:08:13,720 --> 00:08:18,600
And if you think like the attacker,
you can walk through that same process and

156
00:08:18,600 --> 00:08:21,390
then take the precautions
to protect your system.

157
00:08:21,390 --> 00:08:22,152
Right.
That's what it's all about.

158
00:08:22,152 --> 00:08:23,115
All right?

159
00:08:23,115 --> 00:08:26,870
Now, there are a, what's a good word here?

160
00:08:26,870 --> 00:08:28,310
A plethora of tools.

161
00:08:28,310 --> 00:08:32,095
A virtual cornucopia of tools out there
on the internet that you can use for

162
00:08:32,095 --> 00:08:32,896
this, right?

163
00:08:32,896 --> 00:08:35,884
There's commercial tools that cost
tens of thousands of dollars, and

164
00:08:35,884 --> 00:08:39,243
there's open source tools that are
absolutely free and don't cost you a dime.

165
00:08:39,243 --> 00:08:41,580
It's up to you which ones you wanna use.

166
00:08:41,580 --> 00:08:42,850
The more sensitive your network,

167
00:08:42,850 --> 00:08:45,020
obviously, the more money
you're going to pay.

168
00:08:45,020 --> 00:08:47,398
But there are a lot of tools out there.

169
00:08:47,398 --> 00:08:51,340
And I wanna show you guys some examples,
kind of give you an idea of what it's like

170
00:08:51,340 --> 00:08:55,074
to do vulnerability scanning and
penetration testing.

171
00:08:55,074 --> 00:08:58,260
All right, first off,
vulnerability scanning.

172
00:08:58,260 --> 00:09:02,250
All right, you should be doing
vulnerability scanning on your network

173
00:09:02,250 --> 00:09:04,160
every single day, all right.

174
00:09:04,160 --> 00:09:04,900
Every single day.

175
00:09:04,900 --> 00:09:08,750
This is something that should be
a routine activity on your network.

176
00:09:08,750 --> 00:09:12,198
Vulnerability scanning is where you look
at the equipment on your network, and

177
00:09:12,198 --> 00:09:15,090
you say, all right, is there
anything here that's a weak point?

178
00:09:15,090 --> 00:09:15,607
Right.

179
00:09:15,607 --> 00:09:18,170
Now, you might ask yourself,
why scan everyday?

180
00:09:18,170 --> 00:09:19,990
If I scanned yesterday,
why do I need to scan today?

181
00:09:21,040 --> 00:09:22,740
The reason is your network changes.

182
00:09:22,740 --> 00:09:24,430
People make changes to their computer.

183
00:09:25,620 --> 00:09:29,355
People will install updates,
install additional software,

184
00:09:29,355 --> 00:09:32,036
will turn off security features sometimes.

185
00:09:32,036 --> 00:09:32,964
You need to know that.

186
00:09:32,964 --> 00:09:36,370
And so,
you should be scanning every single day.

187
00:09:36,370 --> 00:09:40,034
You can be constantly scanning if you
have something like the Qualys scan guard

188
00:09:40,034 --> 00:09:41,434
boxes, I love those things.

189
00:09:41,434 --> 00:09:43,332
They're these appliances
they just sit there and

190
00:09:43,332 --> 00:09:46,097
constantly scan your network looking for
vulnerabilities that pop up.

191
00:09:46,097 --> 00:09:50,480
That way you're notified right away when
somebody makes a change they shouldn't.

192
00:09:50,480 --> 00:09:51,290
There's other ones.

193
00:09:51,290 --> 00:09:52,720
There's free software that's out there.

194
00:09:52,720 --> 00:09:55,760
There's actually a ton of software
out there for vulnerability scanning.

195
00:09:55,760 --> 00:09:57,965
Which one you choose is really up to you.

196
00:09:57,965 --> 00:09:58,598
Okay.

197
00:09:58,598 --> 00:10:01,355
Let's run down a couple of them.

198
00:10:01,355 --> 00:10:03,624
I know, Nate,
you've got some that you like, and stuff.

199
00:10:03,624 --> 00:10:08,494
But one example of one that's kinda
free that you can mess around with is

200
00:10:08,494 --> 00:10:10,293
SecureCheq by Tripwire.

201
00:10:10,293 --> 00:10:12,950
I'm not the biggest fan of this one.

202
00:10:12,950 --> 00:10:14,860
It's free just for
scanning your own system and

203
00:10:14,860 --> 00:10:17,256
if you wanna scan the rest of
your network, it costs money.

204
00:10:17,256 --> 00:10:19,746
But it also only scans Windows systems.

205
00:10:19,746 --> 00:10:20,541
That's why I don't like it.

206
00:10:20,541 --> 00:10:25,304
If you just wanna scan Windows systems,
SecureCheq is great, but if you wanna

207
00:10:25,304 --> 00:10:31,070
scan Linux or if you wanna scan like Cisco
routers or whatever, it won't do that.

208
00:10:31,070 --> 00:10:33,938
But here, you see an example I
scanned a machine before the show.

209
00:10:33,938 --> 00:10:37,010
And it just ran the quick scan,
it took a few seconds.

210
00:10:37,010 --> 00:10:41,673
And it's got a list of, I don't know,
it's probably about 100 different

211
00:10:41,673 --> 00:10:46,000
things that it tested for here to see
if I had any weaknesses in my system.

212
00:10:46,000 --> 00:10:51,430
And so, like here,
Windows Firewall IPv6 Block Protocols 41.

213
00:10:51,430 --> 00:10:55,410
So, it's got a rule here that says,
hey, this machine

214
00:10:55,410 --> 00:11:00,110
should have this rule in place to secure
IPv6 and, in this case, mine is secured.

215
00:11:00,110 --> 00:11:01,640
I passed that test.

216
00:11:01,640 --> 00:11:02,560
But all the way at the top,

217
00:11:02,560 --> 00:11:06,020
you saw the tests that I've failed and
there were quite a few, right?

218
00:11:06,020 --> 00:11:07,080
Like this one here.

219
00:11:07,080 --> 00:11:09,887
Windows remote desktop configured
to always prompt for password.

220
00:11:09,887 --> 00:11:10,479
All right?

221
00:11:10,479 --> 00:11:14,608
Well, the way I have remote
desktop configured on this system,

222
00:11:14,608 --> 00:11:16,140
I can save my password.

223
00:11:16,140 --> 00:11:18,980
So, I don't have to enter it every
time I connect, cuz I'm lazy.

224
00:11:18,980 --> 00:11:22,620
But that's not a good thing because if
an attacker gets a hold of a system where

225
00:11:22,620 --> 00:11:26,340
I've cached my password, they can
now remote into this one, all right.

226
00:11:26,340 --> 00:11:28,816
So, there's actually a setting we can
configure that changes that behavior.

227
00:11:28,816 --> 00:11:31,678
And says, you know what,

00:29:07,840 --> 00:29:12,630
a sniffer simply records traffic,

A protocol analyzer then takes that

00:29:38,330 --> 00:29:41,020

00:29:41,020 --> 00:29:44,700

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Don explain the solution available to security professionals to help ensure data is secure on host systems, in static environments and the tools to do so. They discuss host security concepts such as host-based intrusion detection systems and OS hardening. They also provide insight on how to protect our data when dealing with embedded systems from SCADA systems to game consoles.

Lastly they also address some of the policies that help and demonstrate the use of Full Device encryption on a smartphone.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee continue the mobile security show previously recorded.  They pickup with some of the other features that can help secure the smart phone.  They discuss some of the different aspects of application control and mobile device management systems that are available for enforcing company security policies regardless of where those devices are in the world.  They also briefly describe the application security aspects that must be considered by a company’s security team before adding software to whitelists.
episodes.title: Mobile Security Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Don take a look at identity management in the form of authentication, authorization, and access control. They compare various authentication services such as RADIUS, Kerberos and SAML. They also discuss concepts to provide authentication with various examples of access controls. They conclude with discussing some best practices with administering account management.
episodes.title: Access and Identity Management

00:05:30,936 --> 00:05:32,800
I didn't have to quiz him.

00:05:32,800 --> 00:05:37,950
I visually saw him and had

113
00:05:37,950 --> 00:05:39,050
I identified and

00:05:39,050 --> 00:05:43,220
recognized that he was who he said he

115
00:05:43,220 --> 00:05:46,630
You do that in computers
on a regular basis.

116
00:05:46,630 --> 00:05:50,420
When I first logged into my computer,
I authenticated.

117
00:05:50,420 --> 00:05:52,490
I provided a user name and password, but

118
00:05:52,490 --> 00:05:57,590
now I'm running it every time I launch
a program, it's identifying me.

119
00:05:57,590 --> 00:06:00,800
It's recognizing that I am who I am,
but it's not authenticating me again.

120
00:06:00,800 --> 00:06:03,710
I'm not having to provide my user name and
password every time I watch a program.

121
00:06:03,710 --> 00:06:05,760
I have an access token, and

122
00:06:05,760 --> 00:06:11,040
that access token is my identity,
and I'm handing that off like crazy.

123
00:06:11,040 --> 00:06:13,430
Every program I run,
every time I access a file,

124
00:06:13,430 --> 00:06:16,420
every time I access a printer,
I'm identify myself.

125
00:06:16,420 --> 00:06:18,700
When you go to a website,
when you go to IT Pro TV,

126
00:06:18,700 --> 00:06:22,300
when you go to our website,
you login, that's you authenticating.

127
00:06:22,300 --> 00:06:25,640
But then every time you click a link
you're going to another page and

128
00:06:25,640 --> 00:06:27,330
you're having to re-authenticate.

129
00:06:27,330 --> 00:06:30,010
But you don't have to enter in you
username and password every time.

130
00:06:30,010 --> 00:06:32,810
You're identifying yourself
with a session token, right?

131
00:06:32,810 --> 00:06:35,490
We track who you are based
on your session ID.

132
00:06:35,490 --> 00:06:38,020
And if your session ID gets reset,

133
00:06:38,020 --> 00:06:40,310
then yeah you'll have to
log back in again, right?

134
00:06:40,310 --> 00:06:44,090
But otherwise you continue to identify
as you're in the system, right?

135
00:06:44,090 --> 00:06:47,330
So there's a couple of different
things that get tied in here that

00:06:47,330 --> 00:06:48,652
get to be a little confusing.

00:06:48,652 --> 00:06:50,530
So you und, you need to understand,
especially for

138
00:06:50,530 --> 00:06:53,755
the exam, the nuances in-between
the three different types.

139
00:06:53,755 --> 00:06:55,560
>> Mm-hm.

140
00:06:55,560 --> 00:06:59,690
>> Alright, so let's take a look at,
at how we do that.

141
00:06:59,690 --> 00:07:03,010
Well, it's really different for
every system.

142
00:07:03,010 --> 00:07:06,810
If you're running Mac OS, if you're
running Linux, if you're running Windows,

143
00:07:06,810 --> 00:07:08,150
if you're running Solaris.

144
00:07:08,150 --> 00:07:11,620
They all have different
authentication mechanisms in place.

145
00:07:11,620 --> 00:07:15,700
So you need to identify which

146
00:07:15,700 --> 00:07:18,930
Well, the Security Plus exam

147
00:07:18,930 --> 00:07:19,620
So they try and

148
00:07:19,620 --> 00:07:23,870
stay out of the proprietary stuff, but
it's kind of hard to with authentication.

149
00:07:23,870 --> 00:07:26,970
One of the most popular
methods that's out there

150
00:07:26,970 --> 00:07:30,220
is the Microsoft Windows Active Directory,
all right?

151
00:07:30,220 --> 00:07:33,268
The Windows Active Directory is designed
for enterprise environments, and, and,

152
00:07:33,268 --> 00:07:37,660
and even small environments can use it, to
be able to have a centralized database of

153
00:07:37,660 --> 00:07:40,310
your user accounts to
authenticate against.

154
00:07:40,310 --> 00:07:44,220
Well, Microsoft didn't create
the Active Directory from scratch.

155
00:07:44,220 --> 00:07:49,064
It's actually built on top of an existing
technology called Kerberos, allright?

00:07:49,064 --> 00:07:50,705
Or Kerberos, or
however you want to say it.

00:07:50,705 --> 00:07:52,244
We had this big debate one
day over how to pronounce it.

00:07:52,244 --> 00:07:53,184
>> [LAUGH]
>> And we went online and

00:07:53,184 --> 00:07:55,710
we found different pages that
would pronounce it for us, and

00:07:55,710 --> 00:07:57,106
they all said it different ways.

161
00:07:57,106 --> 00:07:58,211
>> [LAUGH]
>> So I don't think it really

00:07:58,211 --> 00:07:59,331
matters how you say it.

00:07:59,331 --> 00:08:00,304
So Kira Biros.

164
00:08:00,304 --> 00:08:01,748
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So,

00:08:01,748 --> 00:08:03,764
Kerberos is how I normally say it.

166
00:08:03,764 --> 00:08:05,894
But anyhow, so
that's what it's built upon.

167
00:08:05,894 --> 00:08:08,975
That was actually an authentication
mechanism that was

168
00:08:08,975 --> 00:08:13,706
designed in the Unix world, and so it's
been around a long time, it's very robust.

169
00:08:13,706 --> 00:08:16,295
Of course,
Microsoft messed with it a bit, and so

170
00:08:16,295 --> 00:08:19,220
it's not completely standards compliant.

171
00:08:19,220 --> 00:08:20,970
But they use it pretty heavily.

172
00:08:20,970 --> 00:08:22,110
You can, too.

173
00:08:22,110 --> 00:08:22,670
All right.

174
00:08:22,670 --> 00:08:25,360
Some of the other ones that are out there,
things like LDAP.

175
00:08:25,360 --> 00:08:28,610
LDAP is
the Lightweight Directory Access Protocol.

176
00:08:28,610 --> 00:08:30,900
It really isn't an authentication
mechanism itself.

177
00:08:30,900 --> 00:08:34,030
It's really just a way of
talking to a database.

178
00:08:34,030 --> 00:08:38,870
So, for example, Microsoft's active
directory, it's built using Kerberos for

179
00:08:38,870 --> 00:08:39,980

00:08:39,980 --> 00:08:42,040
It uses LDAP for the request.

181
00:08:42,040 --> 00:08:42,950
So, when someone logs in,

182
00:08:42,950 --> 00:08:45,600
they're actually sending an LDAP
query to the database saying,

183
00:08:45,600 --> 00:08:49,390
hey, here's my username and password or
hash and password, am I allowed in?

184
00:08:49,390 --> 00:08:51,465
And the database is responding back yes or
no..

185
00:08:52,860 --> 00:08:53,780
All right.

186
00:08:53,780 --> 00:08:57,120
But if we wanna go
completely vendor-neutral,

187
00:08:57,120 --> 00:09:00,160
if we want an authentication system
that'll work on no matter what

188
00:09:00,160 --> 00:09:04,460
system we're on, there's really
just two guys that we go to.

189
00:09:04,460 --> 00:09:07,732
And that's RADIUS, and TACACS, all right?

190
00:09:07,732 --> 00:09:11,540
RADIUS, I always screw this one up Ray,
what does it stand for?

191
00:09:11,540 --> 00:09:15,200
>> Remote Authentication
Dial In User Service.

192
00:09:15,200 --> 00:09:17,820
>> Yeah, and so it's the authentication,
I always do remote access, but

193
00:09:17,820 --> 00:09:19,040
it's an authentication protocol.

194
00:09:19,040 --> 00:09:23,940
So remote authentication,
RADIUS was developed a long time ago,

195
00:09:23,940 --> 00:09:27,050
I think it was in the 80s,
so well over 20 years ago.

196
00:09:27,050 --> 00:09:30,670
And it was designed originally for
dial up systems.

197
00:09:30,670 --> 00:09:33,360
If you used an internet
service provider in the 80s or

198
00:09:33,360 --> 00:09:35,990
90s, I think about my first one.

199
00:09:35,990 --> 00:09:40,890
I got my first internet account in
1991 to 1992 right around there, and

200
00:09:40,890 --> 00:09:42,560
you would dial up.

201
00:09:42,560 --> 00:09:45,820
And you would get a log in prompt and
you have to pass off a user name and

202
00:09:45,820 --> 00:09:49,390
password in order to connect and
you'd get a shell screen and off you go.

203
00:09:49,390 --> 00:09:51,435
Your text browsing glory.

204
00:09:51,435 --> 00:09:52,740
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, there was no browsing,

205
00:09:52,740 --> 00:09:57,070
there was no web, but you'd fire up
Gopher or Archie and have a good time.

206
00:09:58,260 --> 00:10:02,990
But that authentication that happened was
authenticating against a RADIUS server.

207
00:10:02,990 --> 00:10:07,180
The cool part about RADIUS is it really
wasn't designed to do authentication

208
00:10:07,180 --> 00:10:10,430
itself, it was designed to be a middleman,
an intermediary.

209
00:10:10,430 --> 00:10:15,220
And, so you can have whatever
user account database you wanted.

210
00:10:15,220 --> 00:10:18,860
You could have any of them, Novell,
Windows, Linux, Unix, whatever,

211
00:10:18,860 --> 00:10:21,520
you can have any kinda user
database that you wanted.

212
00:10:21,520 --> 00:10:23,770
And then you can run RADIUS on top of it.

213
00:10:23,770 --> 00:10:27,720
And then your applications, all your
software, didn't have to know how to talk

214
00:10:27,720 --> 00:10:30,500
to your directory, they just needed to
know how to talk to the RADIUS server.

215
00:10:30,500 --> 00:10:32,400
And they would talk to
the RADIUS server and

216
00:10:32,400 --> 00:10:36,300
say hey, is this a proper login
combination for somebody to get in?

217
00:10:36,300 --> 00:10:39,800
And the RADIUS server would turn
around and talk to that directory.

218
00:10:39,800 --> 00:10:41,720
And get the answer for us.

219
00:10:41,720 --> 00:10:47,850
Because it was so generic and flexible and
usable like that, RADIUS really caught on.

220
00:10:47,850 --> 00:10:51,640
And even though dial-up access is dead,
here we are 30 years later, and

221
00:10:51,640 --> 00:10:55,800
we're still using RADIUS today,
because it's very powerful, all right?

222
00:10:55,800 --> 00:11:02,640
So, it gives us that nice streamline way
to be able to authenticate our users.

223
00:11:02,640 --> 00:11:05,850
Now, RADIUS wasn't the only authentication
protocol that was out there,

224
00:11:05,850 --> 00:11:09,600
there was another one called TACACS,
and you get this acronym?

225
00:11:09,600 --> 00:11:12,050
>> Yep.
>> All right, so TACACS is

226
00:11:12,050 --> 00:11:17,060
Terminal Access Controller
Access Control System.

227
00:11:17,060 --> 00:11:17,830
Rolls right off the tongue.

228
00:11:17,830 --> 00:11:19,140
>> It is a mouthful.

229
00:11:19,140 --> 00:11:24,160
So, with TACACS this one is very,
very similar to RADIUS.

230
00:11:24,160 --> 00:11:27,360
The big difference is in kind
of how it's features work.

231
00:11:27,360 --> 00:11:30,260
So, it does work a slightly
different way than RADIUS.

232
00:11:30,260 --> 00:11:34,580
There's pros and cons with both, but
think of it as like VHS and Betamax.

233
00:11:35,640 --> 00:11:39,400
Over the years we had this battle
between RADIUS and TACACS.

234
00:11:39,400 --> 00:11:43,890
And RADIUS was VHS, and
TACACS was Betamax.

235
00:11:43,890 --> 00:11:46,060
And so, TACACS didn't make it.

236
00:11:46,060 --> 00:11:49,198
Today TACACS is really not used.

237
00:11:49,198 --> 00:11:51,860
Very, very few people make use of TACACS,
but

238
00:11:51,860 --> 00:11:55,970
there is one company that stood
by TACACS and still uses it.

239
00:11:55,970 --> 00:11:57,400
And that company is Cisco.

240
00:11:57,400 --> 00:12:02,040
Now Cisco, being the network leader,
like the industry leader in the networking

241
00:12:02,040 --> 00:12:05,460
realm, that makes it where
TACACS is still pretty relevant.

242
00:12:05,460 --> 00:12:07,950
But the original TACACS is
pretty antiquated, and so

243
00:12:07,950 --> 00:12:11,890
Cisco has been updating it and
modifying it over the years.

244
00:12:11,890 --> 00:12:13,290
And they've modified it so

245
00:12:13,290 --> 00:12:16,940
much that it's no longer compatible
with the original TACACS.

246
00:12:16,940 --> 00:12:21,229
And so the Cisco implementation of it
is called TACACS+, and you'll notice on

247
00:12:21,229 --> 00:12:25,789
the objectives that's specifically the one
they call our right there is TACACS+.

248
00:12:25,789 --> 00:12:31,500
So, that's an important little note,
that plus symbol right there.

249
00:12:31,500 --> 00:12:33,750
So Cisco does still support it.

250
00:12:33,750 --> 00:12:34,810
Nobody else does.

251
00:12:34,810 --> 00:12:38,960
I haven't seen TACACS support on
anything other than Cisco stuff, but

252
00:12:38,960 --> 00:12:40,905
it is still out there,
so be aware of that.

253
00:12:40,905 --> 00:12:41,660
Mm-hm.

254
00:12:41,660 --> 00:12:47,480
>> Yeah, and
one thing with TACACS+that makes it a plus

255
00:12:47,480 --> 00:12:54,120
over the the TACACS is that TACACS+ also
supports multifactor authentication,

256
00:12:54,120 --> 00:13:00,290
and another thing with TACACS is that
it encrypts the whole login process.

257
00:13:00,290 --> 00:13:02,020
So comparing that to RADIUS, so

258
00:13:02,020 --> 00:13:05,192
RADIUS will just encrypt the password,
as it goes across.

259
00:13:05,192 --> 00:13:09,920
So username sent out in plain text,
as where TACACS+,

260
00:13:09,920 --> 00:13:14,220
it will send out the user name and
the password encrypted.

261
00:13:14,220 --> 00:13:15,165
>> Yeah.

262
00:13:15,165 --> 00:13:17,725
And there's all sorts of features
that are that are built into them,

263
00:13:17,725 --> 00:13:22,095
that they have kind of been adding to
over the years to make them better.

264
00:13:22,095 --> 00:13:25,345
We'll find that RADIUS is the one that
we're going to use most commonly.

265
00:13:25,345 --> 00:13:26,825
It's got a lot of the good features.

266
00:13:26,825 --> 00:13:28,735
And I want to show you
guys an example that.

267
00:13:28,735 --> 00:13:31,875
On the exam, they want you to know

00:13:31,875 --> 00:13:34,935
But I want to show you guys
a real practice example.

269
00:13:34,935 --> 00:13:38,965
So I find it easier to understand RADIUS
and TACACS when you compare the two, so

270
00:13:38,965 --> 00:13:41,010
I made this little chart
to help with that.

271
00:13:41,010 --> 00:13:43,380
When you look at these two technologies,

272
00:13:43,380 --> 00:13:48,470
they both provide authentication,
authorization and accounting.

273
00:13:48,470 --> 00:13:50,980
They do all three of
those things that kind of

274
00:13:50,980 --> 00:13:53,625
fall under this authentication umbrella.

275
00:13:53,625 --> 00:13:56,345
But they have different strengths and
weaknesses.

276
00:13:56,345 --> 00:13:59,675
So if you take radius, well,
it's an open standard,

277
00:13:59,675 --> 00:14:03,815
anybody can run it, it does a great
job at authenticating users.

278
00:14:03,815 --> 00:14:08,685
It does a wonderful job, really makes sure
