279
00:14:08,685 --> 00:14:11,205
that we interact with various
databases on the back end,

280
00:14:11,205 --> 00:14:14,220
very powerful stuff,
works really well, all right?

281
00:14:14,220 --> 00:14:17,130
It also does a great job at accounting.

282
00:14:17,130 --> 00:14:21,270
RADIUS keeps excellent logs of when
people access the network, what they did,

283
00:14:21,270 --> 00:14:25,040
and supports storing them in recording
formats where you can get the data out,

284
00:14:25,040 --> 00:14:27,410
it does a really good job of that.

285
00:14:27,410 --> 00:14:30,760
But what RADIUS is weak,
is authorization, right?

286
00:14:30,760 --> 00:14:34,340
When somebody connects to your network,
what are they authorized to do,

287
00:14:34,340 --> 00:14:35,570
what are they allowed to do?

288
00:14:35,570 --> 00:14:39,540
Well, in the RADIUS world, we really just
have whether they're allowed to connect or

289
00:14:39,540 --> 00:14:40,880
not, and that's it.

290
00:14:40,880 --> 00:14:43,740
We don't really have much more for
authorization beyond that,

291
00:14:43,740 --> 00:14:46,520
and you can retrofit it
with a couple of things.

292
00:14:46,520 --> 00:14:48,620
I'll show you an example in a minute.

293
00:14:48,620 --> 00:14:50,720
But it just has basic authorization.

294
00:14:50,720 --> 00:14:52,830
It doesn't do the greatest job there.

295
00:14:52,830 --> 00:14:56,410
TACACS on the other hand, TACACS,
it's not an open standard anymore,

00:14:56,410 --> 00:14:58,245
cuz Cisco's bastardized it so much.

297
00:14:58,245 --> 00:15:00,690
>> [LAUGH]
>> But it is it's still out there.

298
00:15:00,690 --> 00:15:02,200
You can run it.

00:15:02,200 --> 00:15:06,040
It does a great job of authentication,
just like RADIUS does, but

300
00:15:06,040 --> 00:15:10,042
it does a great job at authorization.

301
00:15:10,042 --> 00:15:15,150
With TACACS+, you can get super granular,
and you can say, hey, when this person

302
00:15:15,150 --> 00:15:18,470
connects, they're allowed to run this
command, this command, and this command.

303
00:15:18,470 --> 00:15:20,490
They're not allowed to
run these other commands.

304
00:15:20,490 --> 00:15:22,754
Or they can run this
command between 1 p.m.

305
00:15:22,754 --> 00:15:23,290
and 2 p.m.

306
00:15:23,290 --> 00:15:25,120
in the afternoon and that's it.

00:15:25,120 --> 00:15:28,830
Or they can run this command five times,

308
00:15:28,830 --> 00:15:32,098
So you can get really super
specific in granular with TACACS.

309
00:15:32,098 --> 00:15:33,368
It's really impressive!

00:15:33,368 --> 00:15:37,566
All right, but
TACACS accounting is not very good.

311
00:15:37,566 --> 00:15:40,840
It's just not a great account solution.

312
00:15:40,840 --> 00:15:43,840
It doesn't log data as
well as RADIUS does.

313
00:15:43,840 --> 00:15:48,280
So, in the general world,
most people looked at it and

314
00:15:48,280 --> 00:15:53,150
said well, I'd rather have good
accounting than authorization.

315
00:15:53,150 --> 00:15:54,679
And that's why RADIUS became the winner.

316
00:15:54,679 --> 00:15:58,156
That was the one that people selected,
because it met most people's needs.

317
00:15:58,156 --> 00:16:03,079
But Cisco They said, man, we'd really

318
00:16:03,079 --> 00:16:08,174

319
00:16:08,174 --> 00:16:12,799

their own technology called Cisco ACS,

320
00:16:12,799 --> 00:16:15,463
which is their, access control server.

321
00:16:15,463 --> 00:16:21,012
And Cisco ACS runs both,
it runs RADIUS and TACACS.

322
00:16:21,012 --> 00:16:26,226
And because it's running both, it can
do RADIUS or TACACS for authentication.

323
00:16:26,226 --> 00:16:30,949
It uses TACACS for authentication and
RADIUS for accounting and

324
00:16:30,949 --> 00:16:35,010
by doing that,
they get the best of both worlds.

325
00:16:35,010 --> 00:16:40,070
That's why Cisco has kept TACACS around
when everybody else has let it go.

326
00:16:40,070 --> 00:16:41,930
They've hung onto it for that purpose.

327
00:16:41,930 --> 00:16:43,869
Right, so I wanted to make
sure you guys kinda saw that.

328
00:16:45,190 --> 00:16:48,780
And understood why we still had these
competing technologies even though one was

329
00:16:48,780 --> 00:16:49,790
effectively dead, right?

330
00:16:49,790 --> 00:16:51,030
This is the main reason.

331
00:16:51,030 --> 00:16:51,800
Now on the exam,

332
00:16:51,800 --> 00:16:54,850
you're not gonna see ACS because

333
00:16:54,850 --> 00:16:58,840
They're trying to stay vendor neutral,
but you will see RADIUS and TACACS.

00:16:58,840 --> 00:17:00,280
Those guys will turn up.

All right?

the exam, all right?

00:30:54,900 --> 00:30:58,370
The first one is what's called

00:30:58,370 --> 00:30:59,870
They just say least privilege here, but

00:30:59,870 --> 00:31:02,990
it'll likely be the principle

00:31:02,990 --> 00:31:07,720
And this is stating that, when you give
somebody access to your network, you could

604
00:31:07,720 --> 00:31:11,776
give them full total access to everything,
so they can get in and work, right?

605
00:31:11,776 --> 00:31:13,250
And that would work.

606
00:31:13,250 --> 00:31:16,960
But you'd more than likely be giving
them access to things they don't need

607
00:31:16,960 --> 00:31:17,520
access to.

608
00:31:17,520 --> 00:31:20,470
And when that happens,
it's a recipe for disaster.

00:31:20,470 --> 00:31:23,410
And I gave a story in one of

00:31:23,410 --> 00:31:25,510

00:31:25,510 --> 00:31:29,000

00:31:29,000 --> 00:31:32,020

00:31:32,020 --> 00:31:34,770
So, what you need to do when you're

614
00:31:34,770 --> 00:31:37,380

615
00:31:37,380 --> 00:31:40,460
What they actually need access to, and

616
00:31:40,460 --> 00:31:45,670
when you give them access,
you grant them the bare minimum.

617
00:31:45,670 --> 00:31:48,410
Just to the access they
need to do their job, and

618
00:31:48,410 --> 00:31:51,360
that's going to prevent
them from maliciously or

619
00:31:51,360 --> 00:31:56,070
accidentally getting into areas where

620
00:31:56,070 --> 00:31:57,481
That's called the principle
of least privilege.

621
00:31:57,481 --> 00:32:03,007
When you give access, give people the
least amount of permissions possible for

00:32:03,007 --> 00:32:06,067
them to still be able

00:32:06,067 --> 00:32:08,731

00:32:08,731 --> 00:32:12,276
If you have just one

00:32:12,276 --> 00:32:16,716

00:32:16,716 --> 00:32:19,950
They could be doing all sorts of stuff,

00:32:19,950 --> 00:32:24,610
There was a great story, it was awhile

00:32:24,610 --> 00:32:29,710

00:32:29,710 --> 00:32:33,100

00:32:50,850 --> 00:32:52,560
They terminated the guy, all right.

00:32:57,050 --> 00:33:00,160
He wouldn't give them the password

00:33:00,160 --> 00:33:02,987
So the city was effectively

00:33:02,987 --> 00:33:04,040

>> The guy,

00:33:04,040 --> 00:33:06,060
they ended up having to arrest him,
throw him in jail.

642
00:33:06,060 --> 00:33:06,830
He sat in jail for

00:33:06,830 --> 00:33:11,120
a while under contempt of court before

00:33:11,120 --> 00:33:16,120
But it was a great example of giving

645
00:33:16,120 --> 00:33:18,460
When one person has sole
responsibility of something,

646
00:33:18,460 --> 00:33:23,630
it can lead to bad scenarios like that,
not always, right, but sometimes.

647
00:33:23,630 --> 00:33:27,700
Now, the way we solve that is

648
00:33:27,700 --> 00:33:31,680
We don't give one person
total control of the system.

649
00:33:31,680 --> 00:33:34,110
They could have taken that

00:33:34,110 --> 00:33:36,850

00:33:36,850 --> 00:33:39,230
One who's responsible for the west

652
00:33:39,230 --> 00:33:42,160
the east side, and they're going to
work together to cover that network.

00:33:42,160 --> 00:33:46,640
And they're gonna be cross-trained in each
other's areas so that they can help out,

00:33:46,640 --> 00:33:51,060
and now it's no longer one person in

655
00:33:51,060 --> 00:33:55,600
There's also more serious places where

00:33:55,600 --> 00:33:58,870
Think about double access

00:33:58,870 --> 00:34:02,420

00:34:02,420 --> 00:34:04,721
No one person can just turn the key and

00:34:04,721 --> 00:34:07,410
It takes two people to turn the keys,

660
00:34:07,410 --> 00:34:09,630
No one person has that full duty.

00:34:09,630 --> 00:34:14,380
We can also see it as just dividing up

00:34:21,640 --> 00:34:25,490

00:34:41,160 --> 00:34:42,860

00:34:42,860 --> 00:34:46,202
So if one of those interns backs

00:34:46,202 --> 00:34:49,138

00:34:49,138 --> 00:34:52,443

unprofessional employee could

00:34:56,820 --> 00:34:59,900
So we might separate the duties and

00:34:59,900 --> 00:35:01,440

00:35:01,440 --> 00:35:04,920

00:35:08,010 --> 00:35:11,110

00:35:15,890 --> 00:35:17,430
Access control lists.

00:35:17,430 --> 00:35:21,740

00:35:21,740 --> 00:35:24,681
An access control list, well,

00:35:24,681 --> 00:35:27,220

00:35:27,220 --> 00:35:31,770
So, when you have a file or a folder or
a printer that you're making

00:35:31,770 --> 00:35:36,420

687
00:35:36,420 --> 00:35:40,780
So you create these filters, and you're
filtering based on all sorts of things.

688
00:35:40,780 --> 00:35:43,920
Most commonly, you're filtering based

689
00:35:43,920 --> 00:35:48,325
These usernames, these user accounts

690
00:35:48,325 --> 00:35:50,295
These other user accounts aren't.

00:35:50,295 --> 00:35:56,005
Or these user accounts, maybe Nate, Nate

00:35:56,005 --> 00:35:59,330

00:35:59,330 --> 00:36:01,860

00:36:14,320 --> 00:36:15,190
You can't get in.

00:36:15,190 --> 00:36:16,870
That's an access control list, right.

And there it's enforced with a bouncer.

Now there are many different types

00:36:45,220 --> 00:36:47,880
So let's start with that first one,

00:36:47,880 --> 00:36:52,955
A mandatory access control list is one

00:36:52,955 --> 00:36:53,510

00:36:53,510 --> 00:36:58,270
But technically, the official
definition is that a mandatory

00:36:58,270 --> 00:37:02,760
access list is one that's enforced by
the system, right, by the computer.

716
00:37:02,760 --> 00:37:04,550
But the computer doesn't know what to do.

717
00:37:04,550 --> 00:37:07,640
The computer's under
the control of a system admin.

718
00:37:07,640 --> 00:37:09,780
So, it's the system admin

719
00:37:09,780 --> 00:37:12,390
it's the computer that enforces them,

00:37:12,390 --> 00:37:16,470
But the key component here is

00:37:16,470 --> 00:37:21,790
The end user is not able to modify or

00:37:21,790 --> 00:37:25,370
So a mandatory access list is
one that is set on the system,

723
00:37:25,370 --> 00:37:28,429
enforced by the system, but it's
actually set by a system administrator.

00:37:30,060 --> 00:37:32,350
A discretionary access control list,

00:37:32,350 --> 00:37:35,050
that's one that is set by the user,

00:37:35,050 --> 00:37:38,600
So the user can go in and set, and

00:37:38,600 --> 00:37:40,720
So the admins had one vision of security.

00:37:41,890 --> 00:37:44,110
The end user, it's at their discretion.

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Cherokee begin to discuss available authentications services. In this episode we see examples of AAA ( Authentication, Authorization and Accounting) servers. First, they take a look at RADIUS (Remote Access Dial-in User Service) and see why it is a viable option altho it has been around a while. They then describe Cisco's TACACS+ (Terminal Access Controller Access Control System) and cover details that may help you decide which to implement.

00:26:06.210 --> 00:26:10.590
what would be another reason why I
would choose TACACS+ over RADIUS?

486
00:26:10.590 --> 00:26:13.480
>> Well,
the big advantage of TACACS+ is really

487
00:26:13.480 --> 00:26:15.480
a big advantage if you're running Cisco.

488
00:26:15.480 --> 00:26:19.130
That's pretty much the really
big advantage here.

489
00:26:19.130 --> 00:26:23.420
It really was, at the very beginning,
with TACACS+, Cisco proprietary.

490
00:26:23.420 --> 00:26:26.950
And you probably said, well,
why would you choose to do that, then?

491
00:26:26.950 --> 00:26:29.640
Because it was better in
terms of the features.

492
00:26:29.640 --> 00:26:32.320
And some of the things that
we just mentioned, as well.

493
00:26:32.320 --> 00:26:34.990
But overall, though,
that was this big limitation, too.

494
00:26:34.990 --> 00:26:38.370
So its biggest advantage is
also its biggest feature.

495
00:26:38.370 --> 00:26:43.220
If you already had established all Cisco
equipment, then TACACS was the way to go.

496
00:26:43.220 --> 00:26:48.050
Now, even though you hear
about the idea of TACACS+ and

497
00:26:48.050 --> 00:26:52.480
we can mention that there's actually an
original TACACS out there, but it really

498
00:26:52.480 --> 00:26:56.118
isn't directly compatible when you talk
about the earliest implementations.

499
00:26:56.118 --> 00:27:01.101
Even though TACACS is no longer supported
at the end of the lifetime of where

500
00:27:01.101 --> 00:27:06.322
TACACS was, it still used port 49,
which meant it was still trying to become

501
00:27:06.322 --> 00:27:11.170
the idea of being backward compatible and
the latest ones really could.

502
00:27:11.170 --> 00:27:13.410
You could switch them in if you wanted to.

503
00:27:13.410 --> 00:27:16.290
But the limitation of

504
00:27:16.290 --> 00:27:20.420
being Cisco proprietary was kind of
its biggest disadvantage as well.

505
00:27:20.420 --> 00:27:25.110
Don't forget, the other advantage
of it is that in that day when

506
00:27:25.110 --> 00:27:29.730
RADIUS was really at its heyday, okay,
it only supported IP based networks.

507
00:27:29.730 --> 00:27:33.820
Today, though, it probably just
supports IP networks as well and

508
00:27:33.820 --> 00:27:35.760
you might be wondering,
well, why is that great?

509
00:27:35.760 --> 00:27:38.060
It's great because it's the only
network that's still around.

510
00:27:38.060 --> 00:27:40.780
But TACACS, though,
in the day when it came out,

511
00:27:40.780 --> 00:27:45.750
it supported a ton of different ones, such
as Apple Talk, the Netbox Frame Control,

512
00:27:45.750 --> 00:27:47.120
I wanna make sure I say these right.

513
00:27:47.120 --> 00:27:49.940
Novell Asynchronous Services Interface.

514
00:27:49.940 --> 00:27:54.632
And then X.25 PAD, or
PAD types of connections.

515
00:27:54.632 --> 00:27:58.580
And this is actually very important for
them, because they wanted to be so

516
00:27:58.580 --> 00:28:01.127
universal that,
regardless of what network,

517
00:28:01.127 --> 00:28:03.302
they weren't gonna make you choose IP.

518
00:28:03.302 --> 00:28:05.863
Because they didn't know the direction
that the world was going,

519
00:28:05.863 --> 00:28:08.800
cuz there were so many different
independent protocols out there.

520
00:28:08.800 --> 00:28:11.150
They were supporting everything.

521
00:28:11.150 --> 00:28:16.020
If you were in that situation in which
your network was different, you might've

522
00:28:16.020 --> 00:28:21.500
actually chosen this one since RADIUS only
worked with IP networks instead, okay?

523
00:28:21.500 --> 00:28:26.130
Now the other thing about this is
it really doesn't support 802.1x.

524
00:28:26.130 --> 00:28:29.270
So that could be considered
a disadvantage as well.

525
00:28:29.270 --> 00:28:32.450
And is not recommended like I said,
for remote access.

526
00:28:32.450 --> 00:28:37.250
It's great inside of an internal
network but not on the perimeter too.

527
00:28:37.250 --> 00:28:45.170
And even way back in 1993, they finally
realized, look, nobody is really using it.

528
00:28:45.170 --> 00:28:47.160
One, it was very expensive to implement,

529
00:28:47.160 --> 00:28:50.960
because you had to buy their
particular TACACS server.

530
00:28:50.960 --> 00:28:53.913
AAA server, unlike RADIUS,
it wasn't open source, and

531
00:28:53.913 --> 00:28:57.707
so it was built to specifications, and
the software that they used had to do

532
00:28:57.707 --> 00:29:00.252
everything that they needed
to do which was fine.

533
00:29:00.252 --> 00:29:05.273
But overall, though, when you had a system
like this and nobody was really using it,

534
00:29:05.273 --> 00:29:10.019
except for people that Cisco equipment,
then they decided to release the actual

535
00:29:10.019 --> 00:29:13.819
TACACS Standard itself as
an open standard, back in 1993.

536
00:29:13.819 --> 00:29:15.490
So they just gave it away.

537
00:29:15.490 --> 00:29:20.430
Because it was like, well, there's no use
of us having this and the only way to

538
00:29:20.430 --> 00:29:23.910
get any type of popularity is to see
if we can put it as open standards.

539
00:29:23.910 --> 00:29:26.520
But by that point, the world had moved on.

540
00:29:26.520 --> 00:29:29.970
It's really kind of a shame
cuz fairly decent and

541
00:29:29.970 --> 00:29:32.360
a bit more secure than the idea of RADIUS.

542
00:29:32.360 --> 00:29:37.146
If you think about TACACS+ and DIAMETER
trying to improve on basic RADIUS,

543
00:29:37.146 --> 00:29:40.137
both of those,
even though they might actually

544
00:29:40.137 --> 00:29:44.791
have given us better functional
improvements, never really caught on.

545
00:29:44.791 --> 00:29:48.858
And that's because, well, RADIUS itself
has been the standard all the way through

546
00:29:48.858 --> 00:29:53.010
this point in time with IP networks, and
IP is the only one that's out there.

547
00:29:53.010 --> 00:29:54.630
And everybody just tends to go,

548
00:29:54.630 --> 00:29:59.200
why not use the one that's worked all
the time throughout time instead?

549
00:29:59.200 --> 00:30:02.050
So that's where we are today in terms of

550
00:30:02.050 --> 00:30:06.470
taking just a couple of these different
types of authentication services too.

551
00:30:06.470 --> 00:30:09.280
>> Well, thank you, Ronnie, for

552
00:30:09.280 --> 00:30:12.210
a couple different types
of authentication services.

553
00:30:12.210 --> 00:30:13.640
And thank you guys for tuning in.

554
00:30:13.640 --> 00:30:16.700

555
00:30:16.700 --> 00:30:20.110

556
00:30:20.110 --> 00:30:22.320
Different types that we
have available to us.

557
00:30:22.320 --> 00:30:23.880
So stay tuned for that.

558
00:30:23.880 --> 00:30:25.340
Make sure you don't go anywhere.

WEBVTT

1

Welcome to ITProTV,

2

4

5

>> Welcome to another CompTIA Security+,
episode.

6

7
00:00:17.752 --> 00:00:22.261
This episode is a continuation of
a previous episode, where we were looking

8
00:00:22.261 --> 00:00:26.006
at comparing, different types
of authentication services.

9
00:00:26.006 --> 00:00:29.794
We were able to go ahead, and
take a look at RADIUS and TACACS+.

10
00:00:29.794 --> 00:00:32.290
But we're gonna go ahead and
pick up in this episode.

11
00:00:32.290 --> 00:00:34.600
And with us today, we have Mr Ronnie Wong.

12

13

Well, and thank you for
having me back on the show,

14
00:00:38.705 --> 00:00:41.459
as we continue on with some
more CompTIA Security+.

15
00:00:41.459 --> 00:00:45.208
We wanna take a look at some other
types of authentication methods,

16
00:00:45.208 --> 00:00:47.662
that you're probably going to encounter.

17
00:00:47.662 --> 00:00:52.040
We've already talked about,
like Cherokee said, the idea of RADIUS,

18
00:00:52.040 --> 00:00:54.715
as well as, of course, the TACACS+ here.

19
00:00:54.715 --> 00:00:58.336
And now we're moving on to, well,
something a little bit more advanced,

20
00:00:58.336 --> 00:00:59.612
that we call, Kerberos.

21
00:00:59.612 --> 00:01:03.260
You might hear the term Kerberos,
you name it.

22
00:01:03.260 --> 00:01:06.200
I don't know exactly how it's
supposed to be pronounced, but

23
00:01:06.200 --> 00:01:09.140
this is an authentication method
that was really designed,

24
00:01:09.140 --> 00:01:11.880
I think if I remember right, at MIT.

25
00:01:11.880 --> 00:01:16.670
And they named it after
a three-headed Greek mythological dog,

26
00:01:16.670 --> 00:01:20.090
that guards the gates of Hades,
is what they've actually done here.

27
00:01:20.090 --> 00:01:21.880
To try and say,

28
00:01:21.880 --> 00:01:26.060
hey, here's how the authentication method
works, because that involves three parts.

29
00:01:26.060 --> 00:01:29.460
Now, the key and
the goal behind this though,

30
00:01:29.460 --> 00:01:32.770
is not much that it involves
three separate components.

31
00:01:32.770 --> 00:01:38.440
The key and goal behind this, is something
that we call SSO or single sign on.

32
00:01:38.440 --> 00:01:44.036
Is really the ultimate goal behind,
what this system does.

33
00:01:44.036 --> 00:01:48.491
What we've had access to,
before a lot of times is fairly simple.

34
00:01:48.491 --> 00:01:51.882
Is that every resource on our
network essentially meant,

35
00:01:51.882 --> 00:01:54.384
that you also needed a separate password.

36
00:01:54.384 --> 00:01:56.655
Or even separate user name and
password, for

37
00:01:56.655 --> 00:01:59.440
every one of those different resources.

38
00:01:59.440 --> 00:02:01.960
So let's take for an example,
you had five servers.

39
00:02:01.960 --> 00:02:04.600
Well, that means with those
five different servers,

40
00:02:04.600 --> 00:02:07.080
you'd need a separate username and
password, for that one.

41
00:02:07.080 --> 00:02:11.310
And then you'd go, I need to also get
access to server number two, over here.

42
00:02:11.310 --> 00:02:13.300
Then you'd have to go and
enter in another one, for that one and

43
00:02:13.300 --> 00:02:14.800
the server number three.

44
00:02:14.800 --> 00:02:15.360
You name it.

45
00:02:15.360 --> 00:02:19.060
It actually became almost unmanageable,
for most users.

46
00:02:19.060 --> 00:02:22.234
That we're now keeping 10,
15 different passwords, so

47
00:02:22.234 --> 00:02:24.990
that it could access 10 or
15 different systems.

48
00:02:24.990 --> 00:02:28.184
Kerberos said, what if we could
implement a method though.

49
00:02:28.184 --> 00:02:32.997
That allows you, instead,
to have a single sign on.

50
00:02:32.997 --> 00:02:34.105
And from that point,

51
00:02:34.105 --> 00:02:38.460
have the control to be able to gain
access to each one of those resources.

52
00:02:38.460 --> 00:02:40.590
Once you actually have signed on.

53
00:02:40.590 --> 00:02:45.390
And that is really where the power and
the magic of Kerberos, really begins.

54
00:02:45.390 --> 00:02:47.050
>> We also have to think about, look.

55
00:02:47.050 --> 00:02:52.098
This is definitely undoubtedly,
a more convenient way of authenticating.

56
00:02:52.098 --> 00:02:55.555
But wouldn't it be just as convenient for
that attacker, to go ahead and

57
00:02:55.555 --> 00:02:56.885
compromise the system.

58
00:02:56.885 --> 00:03:00.985
So, you really need to take care of
your password, and not share that out.

59
00:03:00.985 --> 00:03:03.895
And make sure you're following your
company policy, whenever it comes

60
00:03:03.895 --> 00:03:07.965
to their password policy, for
this single sign-on environment.

61
00:03:07.965 --> 00:03:12.310
>> There's no doubt that it really is,
about that whole complete idea.

62
00:03:12.310 --> 00:03:13.400
But how it actually happens,

63
00:03:13.400 --> 00:03:16.640
let's get back to that three
headed dog here, for a moment.

64
00:03:16.640 --> 00:03:18.810
Is that,
there are three components involved, and

65
00:03:18.810 --> 00:03:20.680
they are important components.

66
00:03:20.680 --> 00:03:25.460
But at the same time, its purpose is
a key, the idea of single sign-on.

67
00:03:25.460 --> 00:03:28.890
So when we start talking about those,
particular components there.

68
00:03:28.890 --> 00:03:33.340
You have the client itself, the one
that is trying to of course sign on.

69
00:03:33.340 --> 00:03:37.390
Then we have what we call,
a Kerberos server.

70
00:03:37.390 --> 00:03:39.183
Or a key distribution center, a KDC,

71
00:03:39.183 --> 00:03:41.768
whatever you want to call it here,
is perfectly fine.

72
00:03:41.768 --> 00:03:45.194
It's a server that, essentially, says,
we're gonna do this methodology.

73
00:03:45.194 --> 00:03:48.669
And then, that resource server,
wherever you're trying to access.

74
00:03:48.669 --> 00:03:51.821
All of those are actually
involved in this process, but

75
00:03:51.821 --> 00:03:54.712
how are they involved in this process,
is the key.

76
00:03:54.712 --> 00:04:00.111
So before we kind of, we're not gonna go
super technical into the explanation here.

77
00:04:00.111 --> 00:04:04.031
But let's at least give an analogy,
that I think works well.

78
00:04:04.031 --> 00:04:07.968
That I think will help you to understand,
the process of Kerberos instead.

79
00:04:07.968 --> 00:04:10.555
So, Cherokee,
have you gone to see a movie recently?

80
00:04:10.555 --> 00:04:11.779
>> Yes, I have.

81

>> All right, so
since you've gone to see a movie recently.

00:04:15.585 --> 00:04:19.471

or did you go to the box office?

83
00:04:19.471 --> 00:04:20.770
>> So this is kinda interesting.

84
00:04:20.770 --> 00:04:23.430
I went there to watch the movie.

85
00:04:23.430 --> 00:04:25.970
I wanted to buy the ticket,
but they were sold out.

86
00:04:25.970 --> 00:04:29.000
So I had to buy a ticket for a later time.

87
00:04:29.000 --> 00:04:31.391
Yeah.
So I purchased it, at the theater.

88
00:04:31.391 --> 00:04:33.351
But from the box office,
within the theater.

89
00:04:33.351 --> 00:04:34.190
>> Excellent.

90
00:04:34.190 --> 00:04:37.424
That's actually kind of
the analogy I wanted to use here,

91
00:04:37.424 --> 00:04:41.490
is to understand the working of
how Kerberos, actually works.

92
00:04:41.490 --> 00:04:43.035
The analogy, is fairly simple.

93
00:04:43.035 --> 00:04:46.586
Let's take,
at least a portion of what Cherokee said.

94
00:04:46.586 --> 00:04:49.900
And then we're gonna actually transfer it,

95
00:04:49.900 --> 00:04:51.460
So let's take a look at my screen and
I think,

00:04:51.460 --> 00:04:54.240
this will help us out
just a little bit here.

97
00:04:54.240 --> 00:04:58.500
So let's, we'll kind of add in
the technical elements in a moment.

98
00:04:58.500 --> 00:05:01.420
But let's say that over here at the,

99
00:05:01.420 --> 00:05:03.890
see if I can do this one without

100
00:05:03.890 --> 00:05:04.520
>> There you are.

00:05:04.520 --> 00:05:05.550
>> Yeah, so
>> [LAUGH]

00:05:05.550 --> 00:05:06.240

00:05:06.240 --> 00:05:10.050

at trying to do this with
>> Pretty good.

00:05:13.120 --> 00:05:15.190
>> An actual track pad here.

00:05:15.190 --> 00:05:18.100
Now, when we start to get access.

The client is pretty much,
the most important part here.

00:05:20.830 --> 00:05:24.075
So this is representing someone,

00:05:24.075 --> 00:05:27.260

Now, this particular ticket in

00:05:56.060 --> 00:05:59.201
And once that's actually

00:05:59.201 --> 00:06:02.179

00:06:03.922 --> 00:06:06.227
>> That's how it was for us, last weekend.

00:06:06.227 --> 00:06:08.680
>> So once you have that.

00:06:08.680 --> 00:06:09.450
Then a lot of times,

00:06:09.450 --> 00:06:14.020

00:06:14.020 --> 00:06:18.605
An usher standing after the box office,

00:06:18.605 --> 00:06:20.567

what,

126
00:06:20.567 --> 00:06:23.552
even though they might be standing

00:06:23.552 --> 00:06:27.770
They might ask you to go ahead and

00:06:28.820 --> 00:06:31.550
So, they ask you for the ticket,

00:06:31.550 --> 00:06:35.140

00:06:35.140 --> 00:06:39.070

00:06:39.070 --> 00:06:40.560

00:06:40.560 --> 00:06:41.840

00:06:41.840 --> 00:06:43.270

00:06:48.370 --> 00:06:49.890
>> As a matter of fact,

00:06:49.890 --> 00:06:54.290
>> Yeah, so it has that information

137
00:06:54.290 --> 00:06:55.830
the person who is actually here.

00:06:55.830 --> 00:06:59.550
Now, this is still part of

00:06:59.550 --> 00:07:01.830
Part of that system at this point.

00:07:04.750 --> 00:07:07.590

142
00:07:07.590 --> 00:07:10.010
Does this come from
the system that I know.

143
00:07:11.030 --> 00:07:13.420
And if it does, that's fine.

144
00:07:13.420 --> 00:07:17.040

hey is this your ticket?

145
00:07:17.040 --> 00:07:19.190
What time was it issued?

146
00:07:19.190 --> 00:07:21.271
Where are you trying to get access to?

is never sent across the connection.

285
00:16:34.650 --> 00:16:39.010
What we have though is simply
a challenge that's issued by the server.

286
00:16:39.010 --> 00:16:43.110
So you can think about it, going back to
the idea of just basic algebraic math

287
00:16:43.110 --> 00:16:47.510
here of solving for
x and trying to do that.

288
00:16:47.510 --> 00:16:51.140
So when you have something
like 1 plus x equals 4,

289
00:16:51.140 --> 00:16:54.420
well, they send that over back
to the client essentially.

290
00:16:54.420 --> 00:16:55.320
And then, well,

291
00:16:55.320 --> 00:16:59.060
the client has to generate and figure out,
well, how do I actually solve for x?

292
00:16:59.060 --> 00:17:03.030
They send x back to the server and
the server then goes you're correct.

293
00:17:03.030 --> 00:17:07.308
Or if you don't know what that is then
what happens at that point is that you

294
00:17:07.308 --> 00:17:11.934
have to actually, the server says nope,
that's not the correct connection.

295
00:17:11.934 --> 00:17:14.046
But notice that you never
know what the password is.

296
00:17:14.046 --> 00:17:16.329
It's gonna have to be
generated in some way.

297
00:17:16.329 --> 00:17:20.310
And even though I use a simplistic math
problem, this is generated in a very

298
00:17:20.310 --> 00:17:24.365
highly, much more complex mathematics
in terms of the hash value.

299
00:17:24.365 --> 00:17:28.445
But it keys into the things like your
username and password to be included in

300
00:17:28.445 --> 00:17:32.280
this hash value, and that's how
they generate that for you instead.

301
00:17:32.280 --> 00:17:34.760
So it's neat,
where they already have what's stored,

302
00:17:34.760 --> 00:17:36.260
what they're expecting to see.

303
00:17:36.260 --> 00:17:39.330
And you just have to figure out
what answer you're giving them.

304
00:17:39.330 --> 00:17:41.930
So that's why this is
considered much more secure.

305
00:17:41.930 --> 00:17:43.750
And you use this along with encryption.

306
00:17:43.750 --> 00:17:46.078
You truly do have a much more
secure idea [CROSSTALK]-

307
00:17:46.078 --> 00:17:48.345
>> [LAUGH] You're making that attacker

308
00:17:48.345 --> 00:17:50.239
work for their access there.

309
00:17:50.239 --> 00:17:52.468
They'd have to do some
work to go ahead and

310
00:17:52.468 --> 00:17:54.571
get that authentication to go ahead and

311
00:17:54.571 --> 00:17:58.980
decrypt that encrypted traffic cuz we're
not just sending it in clear text here.

312
00:17:58.980 --> 00:18:03.240
And another cool thing is that
the authentication server will randomly

313
00:18:03.240 --> 00:18:07.500
regenerate that challenge periodically
throughout that session, so

314
00:18:07.500 --> 00:18:11.831
that communication, so that we're
preventing any kind of hijacking or

315
00:18:11.831 --> 00:18:13.830
man in the middle attacks there.

316
00:18:13.830 --> 00:18:15.553
So that's pretty cool as well.

317
00:18:15.553 --> 00:18:19.494
And this was also developed as part of
the point to point protocol as a means of

318
00:18:19.494 --> 00:18:21.725
authenticating users over a remote link.

319
00:18:21.725 --> 00:18:26.765
So you'll see this a lot with any kind
of remote access configurations there.

320
00:18:26.765 --> 00:18:31.571
Typically, one way authentication,
more commonly we'll see Cisco and

321
00:18:31.571 --> 00:18:35.840
Microsoft implementing
mutual authentication there.

322
00:18:35.840 --> 00:18:40.400
And the way you'll see Microsoft's
written out will be MS-CHAP.

323
00:18:40.400 --> 00:18:42.840
That's their variation of this protocol.

324
00:18:42.840 --> 00:18:47.740
And just know that there are other, I
guess, more secure protocols out there or

325
00:18:47.740 --> 00:18:51.370
maybe more popular such as EAP,
extensible authentication protocol.

326
00:18:51.370 --> 00:18:53.370
That's a little more flexible.

327
00:18:53.370 --> 00:18:55.060
So you'll have those options as well.

328
00:18:57.040 --> 00:18:59.824
And next,
we have this idea of single sign-on.

329
00:18:59.824 --> 00:19:05.700
So in most environments we
have this concept of a domain.

330
00:19:05.700 --> 00:19:09.421
Microsoft owns a vast majority
of that marketshare out there so

331
00:19:09.421 --> 00:19:14.261
we can go ahead and create our Microsoft
domains and this idea of single sign-on,

332
00:19:14.261 --> 00:19:18.490
a true single sign-on means that
I'm granted username and password.

333
00:19:18.490 --> 00:19:23.088
I might have to have some other
additional form of authentication,

334
00:19:23.088 --> 00:19:28.350
an authentication factor such as a token,
to go ahead and log on once.

335
00:19:28.350 --> 00:19:32.142
So, single sign on is going to
enable me to log on once and

336
00:19:32.142 --> 00:19:36.664
have access to many network resources so
that I don't have to go and

337
00:19:36.664 --> 00:19:40.945
log onto my email server and
some kind of application server and

338
00:19:40.945 --> 00:19:44.387
everything would just be
pretty time consuming.

339
00:19:44.387 --> 00:19:47.416
Well, with this one username and
password or

340
00:19:47.416 --> 00:19:52.356
this one single sign on you really have
to be careful to make sure you choose

341
00:19:52.356 --> 00:19:56.988
a secure password and you're not
just leaving it exposed in any way.

342
00:19:56.988 --> 00:19:59.060
So If I didn't have single sign on,

343
00:19:59.060 --> 00:20:02.581
let's say that I just had a peer
to peer style network set up,

344
00:20:02.581 --> 00:20:07.350
I would have to have a user account
on every single, individual machine.

345
00:20:07.350 --> 00:20:10.855
However, with single sign on I don't
have to set them up individually.

346
00:20:10.855 --> 00:20:16.380
So it definitely creates, I guess, less
administrative work in the environment.

347
00:20:16.380 --> 00:20:20.380
You go ahead and set up that once on the
administrative side, so it's easier for

348
00:20:20.380 --> 00:20:23.020
the end users and the IT department.

349
00:20:23.020 --> 00:20:26.130
>> Yeah, there's no doubt that single
sign on is the way that you normally

350
00:20:26.130 --> 00:20:29.930
need to do things, once your network
starts scaling out and scaling up,

351
00:20:29.930 --> 00:20:31.380
in other words, growing.

352
00:20:31.380 --> 00:20:35.548
The reason why is trying to ensure that
everybody has access to what they need to

353
00:20:35.548 --> 00:20:38.327
on an individual user basis
becomes a little bit more

354
00:20:38.327 --> 00:20:42.134
unmanageable as you start growing beyond,
let's say, 10 to 20.

355
00:20:42.134 --> 00:20:43.481
Now you have four servers.

356
00:20:43.481 --> 00:20:48.345
Well, you can imagine everybody needing
a single or multiple passwords for

357
00:20:48.345 --> 00:20:50.560
every single user that's there.

358
00:20:50.560 --> 00:20:53.250
Now you don't actually know how to
track every single one and whether or

359
00:20:53.250 --> 00:20:56.030
not they're getting access to
the things that they need to.

360
00:20:56.030 --> 00:20:59.640
So when you do something like that,
remember that, normally, if you're just

361
00:20:59.640 --> 00:21:04.260
using, or implementing something
like multiple passwords like that,

362
00:21:04.260 --> 00:21:09.558
usually the other problem that you have
is you also don't control the access.

363
00:21:09.558 --> 00:21:12.040
In other words, they're password
is essentially gives them access

364
00:21:12.040 --> 00:21:14.920
to everything on those individual servers.

365
00:21:14.920 --> 00:21:18.760
The neat thing about using something
like single sign on in the process

366
00:21:18.760 --> 00:21:23.830
is that we're no longer just depending
on the password to be the last line

367
00:21:23.830 --> 00:21:28.190
of authentication in the process
here as far as access control.

368
00:21:28.190 --> 00:21:31.580
What happens is that even though
you have a single password, now,

369
00:21:31.580 --> 00:21:34.260
you can use that single sign on,

370
00:21:34.260 --> 00:21:39.320
not password itself,
to also limit and control access.

371
00:21:39.320 --> 00:21:43.330
So I might give Cherokee access to
just her folder on a file server.

372
00:21:43.330 --> 00:21:47.960
I might only give her access to, well,
one of these things that she can access on

373
00:21:47.960 --> 00:21:52.800
application server as well but she
doesn't have access to the entire server.

374
00:21:52.800 --> 00:21:56.270
Well, then I can come along and
give myself more access.

375
00:21:56.270 --> 00:21:59.230
And this is without
Cherokee actually knowing

376
00:21:59.230 --> 00:22:03.200
that it's actually happening
not because of her username and

377
00:22:03.200 --> 00:22:06.580
password, but it's because of her own
profile and the way that we control

378
00:22:06.580 --> 00:22:10.030
the access through something we'll
learn about later on in authorization.

379
00:22:10.030 --> 00:22:12.130
So it allows us to combine that and

380
00:22:12.130 --> 00:22:15.180
not just depend on that idea of
a password being a security.

381
00:22:15.180 --> 00:22:19.250
It actually says, look that single
sign on, it gives you access but

382
00:22:19.250 --> 00:22:21.670
it doesn't give you complete access.

383
00:22:21.670 --> 00:22:26.120
So it really is a neat thing for
us to think about as well.

384
00:22:26.120 --> 00:22:30.353
>> Yeah, so like Ronnie said access
control, access control is pretty basic.

385
00:22:30.353 --> 00:22:34.138
It's the idea of just
controlling who has access and

386
00:22:34.138 --> 00:22:38.785
by attaching permissions with
a particular user account you can

387
00:22:38.785 --> 00:22:42.914
easily control who has access
to what network resource,

388
00:22:42.914 --> 00:22:47.890
which brings us to another
concept called implicit deny.

389
00:22:47.890 --> 00:22:51.390
So implicit deny is something you
see very commonly on firewalls.

390
00:22:51.390 --> 00:22:55.280
So they go ahead and configure them by
default to say look we're gonna go ahead

391
00:22:55.280 --> 00:23:00.890
and block all forms of incoming traffic
unless you explicitly allow it.

392
00:23:00.890 --> 00:23:05.646
So, by default I'm implicitly denying
all incoming forms of traffic.

393
00:23:05.646 --> 00:23:07.829
So, that's one way to just kind of secure,

394
00:23:07.829 --> 00:23:11.520
it says concept that you can
implement in a number of ways.

395
00:23:11.520 --> 00:23:15.080
And the last one we wanna go ahead and
take a look at here with this

396
00:23:15.080 --> 00:23:19.045
idea is something called trusted
operating system, so TOS.

397
00:23:19.045 --> 00:23:23.580
We've spoke about this in another episode
and we talked about our common criteria

398
00:23:23.580 --> 00:23:27.800
where the actual operating systems
themselves are going to be having to

399
00:23:29.130 --> 00:23:33.460
be graded with our EALs to be ranked and
make sure that

400
00:23:33.460 --> 00:23:37.950
they're going through the proper steps so
companies are gonna have to submit their

401
00:23:37.950 --> 00:23:41.730
operating systems before we integrate
them into a secure environment.

402
00:23:41.730 --> 00:23:45.765
So there are things that we can do as
administrators on our side, but then

403
00:23:45.765 --> 00:23:49.800
the software companies, hardware companies
have to get approved for as well.

404
00:23:49.800 --> 00:23:53.980
>> Now Cherokee, going back to that idea,
the implicit deny for just a moment.

405
00:23:53.980 --> 00:23:58.247
We also need to understand that this is
normally a standard type of policy that we

406
00:23:58.247 --> 00:23:59.480
put in place.

407
00:23:59.480 --> 00:24:04.380
We want users inside of our network for
what they can do,

408
00:24:04.380 --> 00:24:08.620
when we start getting access to things,
is to be able to have enough privileges to

409
00:24:08.620 --> 00:24:12.480
work inside of that environment and
not need to actually do anything else.

410
00:24:12.480 --> 00:24:16.450
But we also want to deny them access
to everything that they don't need.

411
00:24:16.450 --> 00:24:19.110
>> Exactly.
>> So by doing an implicit deny what

412
00:24:19.110 --> 00:24:23.820
we're actually saying is, we will allow
for only the access that is needed.

413
00:24:23.820 --> 00:24:27.890
In other words the way that Cherokee
described it, explicitly allowing those

414
00:24:27.890 --> 00:24:31.290
because the other way to try and
do this is just to sit and go, okay,

415
00:24:31.290 --> 00:24:33.390
Cherokee, you're gonna
get access to everything.

416
00:24:33.390 --> 00:24:37.830
And after a while, hopefully, I'll come
back and I'll restrict your access.

417
00:24:37.830 --> 00:24:39.258
Well that's where a problem
does end up coming in.

418
00:24:39.258 --> 00:24:40.306
>> Not a good idea, yeah [LAUGH].

419
00:24:40.306 --> 00:24:44.254
>> Because I may forget one, or
all of the sudden now, I say, all right-

420
00:24:44.254 --> 00:24:44.992
>> It's too late.

421
00:24:44.992 --> 00:24:46.910
>> Here's Cherokee's job role.

422
00:24:46.910 --> 00:24:48.420
And now I restrict it and Cherokee goes,

423
00:24:48.420 --> 00:24:50.500
well, this is the only way
I know how to do this.

424
00:24:50.500 --> 00:24:54.130
Well, we have to retrain Cherokee to
actually figure out how to do the job

425
00:24:54.130 --> 00:24:57.130
the right way, which should have been
from the very beginning where we set up

426
00:24:57.130 --> 00:25:00.870
those particular access,
that type of structure.

427
00:25:00.870 --> 00:25:05.900
So by doing that implicit deny,
it really is something that we do rely on.

428
00:25:05.900 --> 00:25:09.650
And it's a great type of policy to
really help us when it comes down to

429
00:25:09.650 --> 00:25:11.100
access control as well.

430
00:25:11.100 --> 00:25:15.950
So, all right Cherokee, we've got
a couple of more things that we have to

431
00:25:15.950 --> 00:25:17.830
actually address, but we are out of time.

432
00:25:17.830 --> 00:25:20.177
Any last words on the authentication?

433
00:25:20.177 --> 00:25:21.475
>> You were doing
a really great job there,

434
00:25:21.475 --> 00:25:25.065
kind of segueing into that concepts
of principle of lease privilege, but

435
00:25:25.065 --> 00:25:28.365
let's go ahead and stop here, so we're not
rushing through it and we'll go ahead and

00:25:28.365 --> 00:25:32.725
start with our authorization and
go ahead and talk about some fundamentals,

437
00:25:32.725 --> 00:25:35.485
some core concepts associated
with security there.

438
00:25:35.485 --> 00:25:38.830
>> All right, that means we're
coming back for a part two.

00:25:38.830 --> 00:25:42.690
So, this is a great place for

00:25:42.690 --> 00:25:46.160
So signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Ronnie Wong.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee take a look into some of the different authorization methods that are available to a security professional.  They discuss principle of least privilege, Discretionary Access Control and Mandatory Access Control along with Role and Rule based Access control.  Along with those authorization controls they describe the use of separation of duties and time of day restrictions.
episodes.title: Understand Access Control Part 2

Let's go ahead and

We had identification, right?

00:01:27.520 --> 00:01:31.840

And we'll take a look at some different

our principal of least privilege here.

So, there's a couple of different way
we could go ahead and approach that.

37
00:02:03.690 --> 00:02:04.920
>> All right, so Cherokee,

38

when we start taking a look at this idea
of the principal of least privilege,

40
00:02:15.310 --> 00:02:17.920
>> Well it's mainly going to

any sensitive information

So for instance, if I had someone

No.
So what we're gonna do is we're gonna go

ahead and restrict access, so

that individual can have a log

that's something we really want to keep

Normally we are going to be separating

an enterprise environment, but

we have a couple different
methods that we'll look at here.

57
00:03:11.250 --> 00:03:14.800
>> Yeah, the idea of using least privilege
is something that every organization

58
00:03:14.800 --> 00:03:20.060
should consider as part of the security
and when dealing with the idea here,

59
00:03:20.060 --> 00:03:22.180
of course, of authorization.

Remember that authorization really

that user to do once
